revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2015}} {{Use Australian English|date=June 2015}} '''The bushranger ban''' refers to a ban on films about [[bushrangers]] that came in effect in Australia in 1911-12. Films about bushrangers had been the most popular genre of local films ever since ''[[The Story of the Kelly Gang]]'' (1906). Governments were worried about the influence this would have on the population and bans against films depicting bushrangers were introduced in [[South Australia]] (1911), [[New South Wales]] (a 1912 amendment to the 1908 New South Wales Theatres and Public Halls ActGraham Shirley & Brian Adams, ''Australian Cinema The First Eighty Years'', Currency Press 1989 p 53) and [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] (1912).[http://australia.gov.au/about-australia/australian-story/film-in-australia "Films in Australia", ''Australia.gov.au''] accessed 2 May 2013{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article15376293 |title=THE CENSOR. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=18 November 1912 |accessdate=4 May 2013 |page=8 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} The decision had a considerable impact on the local industry as it meant filmmakers could not work in a popular genre.[http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/01/28/1043534055850.html Philippa Hawker, "Cinema's anti-hero rides again", ''The Age'', 29 January 2003] accessed 2 May 2013 Australian film production, which in 1911 was one of the highest in the world, went into decline.[http://aso.gov.au/chronology/1910s/ Australian film and television chronology] at [[Australian Screen Online]][http://sensesofcinema.com/2001/feature-articles/oz_western/ More Australian than Aristotelian: The Australian Bushranger Film, 1904-1914by William D. Routt December 2001, ''Senses of Cinema''] accessed 2 May 2013 The ban was still in effect in the 1930s and hurt efforts to make a number of Australian movies, including an adaptation of ''[[Robbery Under Arms]]'' from director [[Ken G. Hall]].{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article51199259 |title=HOLLYWOOD Bushranger Film is "OUT". |newspaper=[[The Australian Women's Weekly]] | date=27 October 1934 |accessdate=2 May 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article17119163 |title=BONUSES FOR FILMS. |newspaper=[[The Sydney Morning Herald]] |date=20 October 1934 |accessdate=12 May 2013 |page=20 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} A ban on a film about [[Ned Kelly]], ''[[When the Kellys Rode]]'' was not lifted until 1942.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article47176334 |title=FILM OF KELLY GANG. |newspaper=[[The West Australian]] |location=Perth |date=7 January 1942 |accessdate=3 May 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} The Hollywood bushranging film ''[[Stingaree (1934 film)|Stingaree]]'' (1934) was screened in every state of Australia except for New South Wales because of the ban.{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article96373244 |title="OUT!" SAYS THE CENSOR. |newspaper=[[Recorder (Port Pirie)|The Recorder]] |location=Port Pirie, SA |date=28 December 1939 |accessdate=23 November 2014 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article51199259 |title=HOLLYWOOD Bushranger Film is "OUT". |newspaper=[[The Australian Women's Weekly]] | date=27 October 1934 |accessdate=23 November 2014 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}} == ''The Story of the Kelly Gang'' == [[File:The Story of the Kelly Gang - Poster.jpg|thumb|Poster for ''The Story of the Kelly Gang'' (1906)]] The bushranger genre of Australian film fictionalized the experiences of [[Bushranger|bushrangers]] from Australian history. Bushrangers were outlaws, most active in the 19th century, and remembered in Australian folklore for their acts of robbery and violent crime, including murder.{{Cite web|url=https://www.records.nsw.gov.au/archives/collections-and-research/guides-and-indexes/bushrangers-nsw|title=Bushrangers in NSW|website=www.records.nsw.gov.au|language=en|access-date=2018-11-17}} The genre showed how the bushrangers’ intimate connection with the bush allowed them to skirt the law and engage in outlaw activity.{{Cite journal|last=Sheckels|first=Theodore F.|date=June 1998|title="New Wave" Cinema's Redefinition of Australian Heroism|url=|journal=Antipodes|volume=12|pages=29-36|via=JSTOR}} Many of the films made before the ban glorified bushrangers, rather than making them seem criminal.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/793340159|title=Historical dictionary of crime films|last=Geoff,|first=Mayer,|isbn=9780810867697|location=Lanham, Md.|oclc=793340159}} Early bushranger films include ''[[Bushranging in North Queensland|Bushranging in Northern Queensland]]'' and ''Robbery of a Mail Coach by Bushrangers.'' Both were released in 1904 and ran five minutes long and six minutes long respectively.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/757462033|title=Australian horror films, 1973-2010|last=1962-|first=Shelley, Peter,|date=2012|publisher=McFarland & Company, Inc., Publishers|isbn=9780786461677|location=Jefferson, N.C.|oclc=757462033}} ''[[The Story of the Kelly Gang]]'', about the bushranger [[Ned Kelly]], was released in [[Melbourne]] on December 26, 1906. ''The Story of the Kelly Gang'' is notable for being the first feature film ever made. At the time of its release, it was considered to be the longest film that had ever been made, running at around seventy to eighty minutes.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nma.gov.au/exhibitions/irish_in_australia/bushrangers|title=National Museum of Australia - Bushrangers|last=|first=|date=|website=www.nma.gov.au|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-12}} Like the majority of the bushranger films that would follow it, ''The Story of the Kelly Gang'' was relatively sympathetic to the outlaws whose lives it fictionalized. As a result, the government of [[Victoria (Australia)|Victoria]] tried to censor it when it was first released, claiming that it was encouraging crime. It was banned in two towns that had a relation to the gang presented in the movie. Despite government discontent, ''The Story of the Kelly Gang'' was a major commercial success, both nationally and internationally. One of the producers of the film stated that it made 25,000 pounds, in comparison to its budget of 1000 pounds. == Bushranger films from 1906 to 1912 == [[File:Mad Dog Morgan.jpg|thumb|252x252px|Wood carving of the bushranger Dan "Mad Dog" Morgan]] The success of ''The Story of the Kelly Gang'' encouraged filmmakers to produce even more bushranger films.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/587198895|title=Australia & New Zealand|date=2010|publisher=Intellect Books|others=Goldsmith, Ben, 1967-, Lealand, Geoffrey.|isbn=9781841503738|location=Bristol, UK|oclc=587198895}} Between 1900 and 1914, one hundred and sixteen bushranger films were made in Australia.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/910448038|title=Censorship : a World Encyclopedia.|last=Stockbridge|first=Sally L.|date=2015|publisher=Taylor and Francis|year=|isbn=9781136798641|editor-last=Jones|editor-first=Derek|location=Hoboken|pages=|chapter="Australia: Film and Video"|oclc=910448038}} Most, if not all, of these films focused on the lives of white male bushrangers.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/435778744|title=The A to Z of Australian and New Zealand cinema|last=Albert.|first=Moran,|date=2009|publisher=Scarecrow Press|others=Vieth, Errol, 1950-, Moran, Albert.|isbn=9780810863477|location=Lanham|oclc=435778744}} A few of the most significant bushranger films made in this period include ''[[Thunderbolt (1910 film)|Thunderbolt]]'' (1910), ''[[Captain Midnight, the Bush King]]'' (1911), multiple adaptations of the classic bushranger novel ''[[Robbery Under Arms]]'', and ''[[Dan Morgan (film)|Dan Morgan]]'' (1911). ''Dan Morgan'' was notable for depicting its protagonist, the historical outlaw [[Dan Morgan (bushranger)|Dan Morgan]], as a true criminal, rather than an anti-hero.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/793340159|title=Historical dictionary of crime films|last=Geoff,|first=Mayer,|isbn=9780810867697|location=Lanham, Md.|oclc=793340159}} The graphic violence of ''Dan Morgan'' was unlike the content of any bushranger film before it, and it spurred the governments of New South Wales and Victoria to pass regulations on film content the very next year. == Theatres and Public Halls Act of 1912 == In 1912, New South Wales’s Theatres and Public Halls Act was amended to directly target the content of films. Specifically, the 1912 amendment was meant to prohibit the screening of “objectionable” films – films with{{Cite news|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/117688374?searchTerm=bushranger%20film%20ban%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20&searchLimits=l-availability=y|||l-australian=y|||l-decade=191|title=Censoring Films: Regulations Gazetted.|last=|first=|date=November 6, 1912|work=Evening News|access-date=|location=Sydney, NSW}}
“scenes suggestive of immorality or indecency, executions, murders, or other revolting scenes; scenes of debauchery, low habits of life, or other scenes such as would have a demoralizing effect on young person; successful crime, such as bushranging, robberies, or other acts of lawlessness…”
The New South Wales government claimed that the Theatres and Public Halls Act of 1912 was meant to protect film audiences, particularly young audiences, from “injurious influence.” This included the criminal activity of bushrangers. They were also against most bushranger films' depiction of the police as an antagonistic force. Anyone going against the Act could be subject to a fine of up to 20 pounds. The police were placed in charge of censoring films in accordance with the standards set by the 1912 amendment. They were to look over film summaries in order to determine their appropriateness, and could also demand a screening of a film if they thought it contained any “objectionable” material. == Censorship of film imports and exports == In 1917, state censor boards were supplemented by a national Commonwealth Film Censorship Board. The national Censorship Board judged the content of imported films, primarily those from Britain and the USA. State censor boards could take additional action if they believed that the Commonwealth Film Censorship Board had acted too leniently. In 1920, the Chief Secretary of Victoria attempted to prevent the development of a film about the [[Kelly Gang]] that he believed would spread a negative image of Victoria. The Australian government feared that attempts to ban the film in Australia would result in its international distribution. The government worried that the international release of any films that portrayed Australia negatively would damage the country’s global image. Though the government could not intervene in the creation of a film, it could control its distribution. That year, the Minister of Customs was placed in charge of regulating the export of films from Australia to other parts of the world.{{Cite news|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/127388446?searchTerm=bushranger%20film%20ban%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20&searchLimits=l-decade=192|||l-australian=y|title=Export of Films: Why Prohibition Was Applied.|last=|first=|date=January 3, 1920|work=The Maitland Weekly Mercury|access-date=}} == Impact of the ban on Australian film == Before the bushranger ban, bushranging had been the most common topic for Australian films. After the ban, film production in Australia decreased as creators lost their most popular genre and the audiences it drew to the theatres. Unsurprisingly, the new censorship forces were met with discontent from the Australian film industry. H.M. Hawkins, the managing director of [[Spencer's Pictures|Spencer’s Pictures]], argued that censorship would limit the industry’s ability grow, since depictions of crime were essential to the creation of a successful drama.{{Cite news|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/228833817?searchTerm=bushranger%20film%20ban%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20&searchLimits=l-availability=y|||l-australian=y|||l-decade=191|title=Film Censorship "Will Cripple the Picture Business"|last=|first=|date=November 17, 1912|work=The Sun|access-date=|location=Sydney, NSW}} In December of 1916, a week after a violent film about gambling was prevented from being screened, a group of Australian film exhibitors gathered to discuss the impact of censorship on their business.{{Cite news|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/121345461?searchTerm=bushranger%20film%20ban%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20&searchLimits=l-availability=y|||l-australian=y|||l-decade=191|title=Film Censorship: Exhibitors Meet To-Day|last=|first=|date=December 17, 1916|work=Sunday Times|access-date=|location=Sydney, NSW}} They expressed frustration with the fact that the police were in charge of film censors, claiming that the police department was most threatened by bushranger films' depictions of crime and as a result was hardest on crime in film over all other content. They also pointed out that films were being censored far more harshly than written material with the same content. The primary threat the New South Wales government saw in bushranger films was their apparent glorification of crime. As a result, some bushranger films could get through the censors if the criminal activity they depicted was condemned within the film and law enforcement wasn’t shown in a negative light. However, because of the stigma that had developed around the genre, few directors were willing to risk making bushranger films, especially if they had established reputations to uphold. In 1920, the director [[Raymond Longford]] avoided adapting ''Robbery Under Arms'' in order to preserve his status within the Australian film industry. == Decline of the bushranger ban == The end of the bushranger ban was arguably indicated by the 1942 release of ''[[When the Kellys Rode]]'' in New South Wales. ''When the Kellys Rode'', a bushranger film about the Kelly Gang, had been banned in 1934. It was the last film banned under the Theatres and Public Halls Act for bushranging content.{{Cite news|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/18077432?searchTerm=bushranger%20film%20ban%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20&searchLimits=l-australian=y|||l-decade=194|title=Film Banned in N.S.W.: 'Brighton Rock'|last=|first=|date=July 10, 1948|work=The Sydney Morning Herald|access-date=}} [[Jack Baddeley]], Chief Secretary of New South Wales, finally allowed it to screen in New South Wales in the midst of [[World War II]], claiming that the crimes that the film depicted were nothing compared to “the unbridled horrors of war.”{{Cite news|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/205278235?searchTerm=bushranger%20film%20ban%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20&searchLimits=l-availability=y|||l-australian=y|title=Ban on Kelly Gang Film Removed|last=|first=|date=January 7, 1942|work=The Age|access-date=|location=Melbourne, Victoria}} After ''When the Kellys Rode'', the Theatres and Public Halls Act was invoked again by Chief Secretary Baddeley to ban the violent British film ''[[Brighton Rock (1948 film)|Brighton Rock]]''. ''Brighton Rock'' had been allowed into Australia by the Commonwealth Film Censorship Appeals Board, and the Chief Secretary would state no reason for the decision to ban the film in New South Wales. By the time that bushranger ban was finally lifted in the 1940s, the popularity of and demand for the genre had already faded. Even after bushranging in film was legal, at least one attempt to produce a bushranger film was met with discontent from Australian citizens. In 1947, residents of [[Glenrowan, Victoria|Glenrowan]], a town associated with the Kelly Gang, protested against [[Harry Southwell]]’s plans to shoot a film about Ned Kelly in their town. Glenrowan’s farmers sent a petition to Parliament to ban the film, claiming that bushranger films had given a negative reputation to the descendants of the Kelly Gang.{{Cite news|url=https://trove.nla.gov.au/newspaper/article/161306059?searchTerm=bushranger%20film%20ban%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20&searchLimits=l-australian=y|||l-decade=194|title=Ned Kelly Revival: Bitter Opposition to Film|last=|first=|date=August 16, 1947|work=National Advocate|access-date=|location=Bathurst, New South Wales}} ==Select bushranger films== ===Before the ban=== *''[[Bushranging in North Queensland]]'' (1904) *''[[The Story of the Kelly Gang]]'' (1906) *''[[Robbery Under Arms (1907 film)|Robbery Under Arms]]'' (McMahon version) (1907) *''[[Robbery Under Arms (1907 Tait film)|Robbery Under Arms]]'' (Tait version) (1907) *''[[Thunderbolt (1910 film)|Thunderbolt]]'' (1910) *''[[Moonlite]]'' (1910) *''[[The Life and Adventures of John Vane, the Notorious Australian Bushranger]]'' (1910) *''[[A Tale of the Australian Bush]]'' (1911) *''[[Captain Midnight, the Bush King]]'' (1911) *''[[Captain Starlight, or Gentleman of the Road]]'' (1911) *''[[The Lady Outlaw]]'' (1911) *''[[Dan Morgan (film)|Dan Morgan]]'' (1911) *''[[Ben Hall and his Gang]]'' (1911) *''[[Bushranger's Ransom, or A Ride for Life]]'' (1911) *''[[Frank Gardiner, the King of the Road]]'' (1911) ===Affected by the ban=== *''[[Moondyne#Film|Moondyne]]'' (1913) *''[[The Kelly Gang]]'' (1920) *''[[Robbery Under Arms (1920 film)|Robbery Under Arms]]'' (1920) *''[[The Shadow of Lightning Ridge]]'' (1920) *''[[The Gentleman Bushranger]]'' (1921) *''[[When the Kellys Were Out]]'' (1922) *''[[Trooper O'Brien]]'' ([[1928 in film|1928]]) *''[[When the Kellys Rode]]'' (1934) *''[[Stingaree (1934 film)|Stingaree]]'' (1934) ==References== {{reflist|2}} [[Category:Film censorship]] [[Category:Cinema of Australia]] [[Category:Censorship in Australia]] [[Category:Bushranger films]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox video game | title = Chameleon Run | image = Chameleon Run.png | developer = [[Hyperbolic Magnetism]] | publisher = [[Noodlecake Studios]] | engine = Unity 3d | platforms = [[iOS]], [[Android (operating system)|Android]], [[Windows Phone]], [[Nintendo Switch]] | released = 7 April 2016<ref name="Gamescz">{{cite web|last1=Poláček|first1=Petr|title=Do boje proti vykrádačkám vyběhne český Chameleon Run na začátku dubna - Games.cz|url=http://games.tiscali.cz/datum-vydani/do-boje-proti-vykradackam-vybehne-cesky-chameleon-run-na-zacatku-dubna-273367|website=Games.cz|accessdate=13 May 2016}}</ref> | genre = [[Action video game|Action]] | modes = [[Single-player]] | designer = Ján Ilavský | programmer = Ján Ilavský | writer = | composer = Ján Ilavský }}Nintendo Switch ''Chameleon Run'' is a 2016 video game for iOS, Android, Windows Phone and Nintendo Switch. It is developed by Hyperbolic Magnetism. The creators of beat Saber and many more indie games.
==Development== The game was originally created as a [[Ludum Dare]] prototype by [[Ján Ilavsky]]. Ilavský later decided to remake it into a full-length game when he saw how many clones of Chameleon Run Design Of Limbless Of [[Ubisoft]] [[Rayman]] came up on AppStore and Google Play that used his [[Source code]].<ref name="Gamescz">{{cite web|last1=Poláček|first1=Petr|title=Do boje proti vykrádačkám vyběhne český Chameleon Run na začátku dubna - Games.cz|url=http://games.tiscali.cz/datum-vydani/do-boje-proti-vykradackam-vybehne-cesky-chameleon-run-na-zacatku-dubna-273367|website=Games.cz|accessdate=13 May 2016}}</ref>
==Gameplay== Chameleon Run is an auto runner and does require the user to do anything else but short and long jumps by holding the screen and to allow colour change between 2 of the same characters, the first is purple and the second is yellow. Player controls his cube-like character that moves to the right and forward direction. The player's task is to help him to get to the end on the white cubic road. He has to jump over obstacles and pits. The game features an original mechanic <!--mechanism?--> that the player can touch only objects that have the same colour as his character. Player has to switch his player´s colour so that he can move on different platforms. Every level features three tasks—finish level, collect all coins and crystals and to finish level without switching colour.<ref name="TechCrunch">{{cite web|last1=Williams|first1=Felicia|title=Game Review: Chameleon Run|url=https://techcrunch.com/2016/04/15/game-review-chameleon-run/|website=TechCrunch|accessdate=13 May 2016}}</ref>
==Reception== Chameleon Run has received generally positive reviews from critics. It holds 85 percent on Metacritic.<ref name="MC">{{cite web|title=Chameleon Run|url=http://www.metacritic.com/game/ios/chameleon-run|website=Metacritic|accessdate=13 May 2016}}</ref>
''[[Pocket Gamer]]'' called Chameleon Run "A fresh and exciting take on the autorunner." It praised its gameplay and its mechanics including the colour-switching mechanic.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Slater|first1=Harry|title=Chameleon Run Review|url=http://www.pocketgamer.co.uk/r/iPad/Chameleon+Run/review.asp?c=69701|website=Pocket Gamer|accessdate=13 May 2016}}</ref>
''[[TouchArcade]]'' praised the colour-switching mechanic and environment that is "full of life." It also praised challenges and visuals.<ref name="Touch">{{cite web|last1=Carter|first1=Chris|title='Chameleon Run' Review - A Change of Color|url=http://toucharcade.com/2016/05/03/chameleon-run-review/|website=TouchArcade|accessdate=13 May 2016|date=3 May 2016}}</ref>
Chameleon Run is one of winners of [[Apple Design Awards]] 2016.<ref name="CNET: anatomy">{{Cite web |last1=Starr |first1=Michelle |title=Apple Design Awards go to Lara Croft Go and an anatomy app |work=[[CNET]] |date=2016-06-13 |url=http://www.cnet.com/news/apple-design-awards-go-to-lara-croft-go-medical-anatomy-app/ |accessdate=2016-06-16 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Chameleon Run has sold over 260,000 copies as of 1 July 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Jan Split Ilavsky on Twitter|url=https://twitter.com/Split82/status/748789695232872448|accessdate=1 July 2016}}</ref> Sales were 400,000 units as of February 2017.<ref>{{cite web|title=Českou hrou roku 2016 je Samorost 3 od studia Amanita Design {{!}} Kultura|url=http://www.lidovky.cz/ceskou-hrou-roku-2016-je-samorost-3-dof-/kultura.aspx?c=A170210_213407_ln_kultura_ELE|website=Lidovky.cz|accessdate=10 February 2017|date=10 February 2017}}</ref>
Chameleon Run is nominated for 5 [[Czech Game of the Year Awards]]. It is nominated in categories Best Game, Best Mobile Game, Best Game Design, Best technological solution and Best Visuals. Winners were announced on 10 February 2016.<ref>{{cite web|title=Nominace - ČESKÁ HRA ROKU 2016|url=http://ceskahraroku.cz/nominace-2016/|website=ČESKÁ HRA ROKU 2016|accessdate=27 January 2017|language=cs-CZ}}</ref> Chameleon Run won in categories Best mobile game of the year and Best design.<ref>{{cite web|title=Českou hrou roku 2016 je Samorost 3 {{!}} ČeskéNoviny.cz|url=http://www.ceskenoviny.cz/zpravy/ceskou-hrou-roku-2016-je-samorost-3/1448722|website=www.ceskenoviny.cz|accessdate=10 February 2017|language=cs}}</ref>
== Other Version == A Nintendo Switch version of the game is announced, launching on June 14, 2018. This version is called Chameleon Run: Deluxe edition and it will include six new levels unique to Switch and a special fourth objective to complete on each level.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nintendolife.com/news/2018/06/chameleon_run_sprints_onto_nintendo_switch_with_a_deluxe_edition|title=Chameleon Run Sprints Onto Nintendo Switch With A Deluxe Edition|last=Life|first=Nintendo|date=2018-06-01|work=Nintendo Life|access-date=2018-06-04|language=en-GB}}</ref>.
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.chameleonrun.com/ Official Site]

{{Multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=February 2016}} {{Notability|date=October 2009}}}} {{Coord|53.7546|-0.3489|display=title|region:GB_scale:2000}}
'''Club Déjà Vu''' is the name of a long running club night based in [[Kingston upon Hull]] in the [[East Riding of Yorkshire]], England. Club Déjà Vu was originally started by Terry Spamer in 1992 as "Delightful" at the KU2 club. The night ran every two weeks on a Fridays from 10 pm to 2am. [[DJ]]s that played at the club were John Kelly, Allister Whitehead, [[John Digweed]] and Al Mackenzie from [[D Ream|D:Ream]].
Déjà Vu is currently held at the Funktion Hull [[nightclub]] on [[Anlaby Road]] in the city.
Notable DJs who have appeared at Déjà Vu include: [[Pete Tong]], [[Norman Jay MBE]], [[Danny Rampling]], [[Graeme Park]], [[Sarah Main]], [[Chris Lake]], [[Masters at Work]], [[Erick Morillo]], [[Lee Burridge]], [[Sandy Rivera]], [[David Morales]], [[Mousse T.]], [[Pete Heller]], [[Azzido da Bass]], [[Junior Sanchez]], [[Jose Nuñez (DJ)|José Nunez]], [[Kevin Saunderson]], [[Full Intention]], [[Manumission]], [[Dave Seaman]], [[Roger Sanchez]], [[Knee Deep]], [[Danny Rampling]], [[Bob Sinclar]], [[Martin Solveig]], [[DJ Sneak]], [[Robbie Rivera]], [[Steve Angello]], [[Kerri Chandler]], [[Steve Lawler]], [[DJ Disciple]], [[Eric Prydz]], [[Joey Negro]], [[Michael Gray (DJ)|Michael Gray]], [[Todd Terry]], [[Seamus Haji]], [[Brandon Block]], [[Jon DaSilva]], [[Ashley Beedle]], [[Paul Harris (musician)|Paul Harris]], [[Soul Avengerz]], [[Howard Donald]], [[Hardsoul]], [[Ian Carey]], [[Danny Howells]], [[StoneBridge (DJ)|Stonebridge]], [[Tom Novy]], [[Shapeshifters (band)|Shapeshifters]], [[DJ Falcon]] and [[Terry Hunter]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070104112042/http://www.dontstayin.com/parties/deja-vu|title=Deja Vu group - DontStayIn|date=4 January 2007|website=Web.archive.org|accessdate=19 January 2018}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.clubdejavu.net/ Official website]

{{Infobox comic book title |image = ComicCavalcade6.jpg |caption = Green Lantern, Wonder Woman and the Flash do their bit for the war: ''Comic Cavalcade'' #6 (Spring 1944), cover art by [[Paul Reinman]]. |schedule = '''Quarterly:'''
#1-13
'''Bi-monthly:'''
#14-63 |ongoing = Y |publisher = [[DC Comics]] |startmo = Winter |startyr = 1942 |endmo = Jun/Jul |endyr = 1954 |issues = 109 |main_char_team = [[Jay Garrick|Flash]]
[[Alan Scott|Green Lantern]]
[[Wonder Woman]] |writers = [[Bill Finger]]
[[Gardner Fox]]
[[Sheldon Mayer]]
[[William Moulton Marston]] |artists = [[Sheldon Mayer]]
[[Irwin Hasen]]
[[H.G. Peter]]
[[Martin Nodell]] |pencillers = |inkers = |letterers = |colorists = |editors = |creative_team_month = |creative_team_year = |creators = |TPB = |ISBN = |TPB# = |ISBN# = |subcat = |altcat = |sort = Comic Cavalcade |addpubcat# = }} '''''Comic Cavalcade''''' was an [[anthology]] comic book published by [[DC Comics]] from 1942 to 1954. Most American comic book publishers in the 1930s and 1940s [[Golden Age of comic books]] published anthology titles that showcased a variety of characters, usually with one star—such as [[Alan Scott|Green Lantern]] in ''[[All-American Comics]]'' or [[Wonder Woman]] in ''[[Sensation Comics]]''. ''Comic Cavalcade'', however, featured both those star characters as well as the [[Jay Garrick|Flash]], a star in his own namesake title as well as the spin-off ''[[All-Flash]]''. At 96 pages initially, ''Comic Cavalcade'' was about one-and-one-half-times the length of the average comic book of the time. It was priced at 15 cents, when the average comic cost a dime. Many stories in ''Comic Cavalcade'' were scripted by other than the characters' regular writers, for deadline reasons.{{citation needed|date=March 2015}} [[Batman]] writer [[Bill Finger]], for example, would occasionally write Flash stories for ''Comic Cavalcade'' when regular Flash writer [[Gardner Fox]] was preoccupied with other projects. One non-superhero ongoing character introduced in ''Comic Cavalcade'' was newspaperman Johnny Peril. His roots, prior to his first appearance, came in the one-off story "Just a Story" in issue #15 (July 1946), by writer-artist [[Howard Purcell]]. With issue #22 (Sept. 1947), the anthological "Just a Story" series gained Peril as, generally, a witness or narrator rather than as an integral part of the narrative. With this issue, the series title became "Johnny Peril Tells Just a Story", eventually changed to "Johnny Peril's Surprise Story" as Johnny became the series' two-fisted hero until the series ended with issue #29 (Nov. 1948). The character went on to appear in his own feature in ''[[All-Star Comics]]'', ''Danger Trail'' and ''[[Sensation Comics]]'' through 1953. He returned in the [[Silver Age of Comic Books]] in 1958, in ''[[The Unexpected]]''.[http://toonopedia.com/jperil.htm Johnny Peril] at [[Don Markstein's Toonopedia]]. [https://www.webcitation.org/6XEJtuSP0 Archived] from the original on March 22, 2015. Initially published quarterly, the title went bi-monthly beginning with #14 (April–May [[1946 in comics|1946]]). It was revamped completely with #30 (December–January [[1948 in comics|1948]]), becoming a [[funny-animal]] [[humor]] book when [[superhero]]es faded from popularity in the post-war era. Featured were [[animator]] [[Frank Tashlin]]'s [[movie]]-[[cartoon]] duo ''[[The Fox and the Crow]]'', along with cartoonist [[Woody Gelman]]'s creations, ''[[The Dodo and the Frog]]'' and ''[[Nutsy Squirrel]]''. The book's length by this time had been reduced to 76 pages. The title would later be referenced with DC's 1970s ''[[Cancelled Comic Cavalcade]]'' series. ==References== {{Reflist}} * [http://www.comics.org/ The Grand Comics Database] * [http://www.dcindexes.com/index.php Mike's Amazing World of DC Comics] * [http://www.wonderland-site.com/html/comix/comics08-01.htm Wonderland, the Ultimate Wonder Woman Site: ''Comic Cavalcade''] * [http://www.toonopedia.com/fox_crow.htm Don Markstein's Toonopedia: The Fox and the Crow], [http://www.toonopedia.com/wonderwo.htm Wonder Woman], [http://www.toonopedia.com/lantern1.htm Green Lantern] and [http://www.toonopedia.com/flash1.htm The Flash] {{Flash}} {{Green Lantern}} {{Wonder Woman}} [[Category:American comics magazines]] [[Category:All-American Publications titles]] [[Category:Comics by Robert Kanigher]] [[Category:DC Comics titles]] [[Category:1942 comics debuts]] [[Category:1954 comics endings]] [[Category:Magazines established in 1942]] [[Category:Magazines disestablished in 1954]]

revision.text:
[[File:Johansen Viggo - Radosne Boże Narodzenie.jpg|thumb|right|250px|The Danish tradition of dancing around the [[Christmas tree]] still takes place every year in [[Danebod]], the first Danish settlement in Minnesota.<ref>Minnesota Society (2005). ''Architecture Minnesota, Volume 31''. Bill Dorn Associates, Incorporated. Page 62.</ref>]] '''Danish folk dance''' is characterized by being easy going, gentle, and relatively easy to learn. Danish folk dance is mainly a [[social dance]] involving groups or groups of couples of dancers, often designed for large gatherings. The dances were supposed to be simple enough for everyone to join in.<ref>Solway, Andrew (2008). ''Country and Folk Dance''. Heinemann-Raintree Library. Page 22. {{ISBN|9781432913809}}.</ref> Danish folk dances are made for social- and educational purposes, generally speaking not for exhibitional purposes.<ref>Bovbjerg, Viggo (1917). ''Music for Danish folk dances''. Recreation Department, Chicago School of Civics and Philanthropy. First page: “Foreword”.</ref> [[File:Folkedans Rømø.jpg|thumb|left|250px|Folk-dancing on the island of [[Rømø]].]] The canonized history of Danish folk dance highlights a performance by Philochoros in [[Copenhagen]] in 1899 with some Danish students in the audience as a triggering factor. The students were immediately so inspired that they started a folk dance club. In 1901 some of the same students who were now students of gymnastics founded a formal organization, the Danish Association for the Promotion of Folk-Dancing (Foreningen til Folkedansens Fremme).<ref>Hoppu, Petri and Karen Vedel (2014). ''Nordic Dance Spaces: Practicing and Imagining a Region''. Ashgate Publishing, Ltd. Page 147. {{ISBN|9781409470014}}.</ref> The number of folk dance organizations and societies continued to grow throughout [[Denmark]] for the following two decades.<ref>Nielsen, Erica M (2011). ''Folk Dancing''. ABC-CLIO. Page 45. {{ISBN|9780313376894}}.</ref> Danish Folk-Dancers was established in 1929 and is an organization that still arranges courses for folk dancers, and every year folk dance festivals are organized. The effect of all of this had led to a certain uniformity in the performance of the Danish folk dances, thus reducing regional differences between local dances and traditions within Denmark.<ref>Peter, Saint (1983). ''Dance Studies, Volume 7''. Centre for Dance Studies. Page 14.</ref> These societies and organizations also contributed to help preserve the Danish traditional costume as well as the [[folk dance]].<ref>O’Brien, Joan (2002). ''Children's Folk Costumes''. Courier Corporation. Page 1. {{ISBN|9780486423869}}.</ref> These groups produces journals, books, photographs, recipes, costumes, props, and other cultural artifacts as well. They organized demonstrations, theatrical exhibitions, festivals, open houses for dancing, and other social events.<ref>Nielsen, Erica M (2011). ''Folk Dancing''. ABC-CLIO. Page 45. {{ISBN|9780313376894}}.</ref>
== References == <references/>
== See also == *[[Faroese dance]]
{{Dance}}

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contributions/64.228.218.109|64.228.218.109]] ([[User talk:64.228.218.109|talk]]) ([[WP:HG|HG]]) (3.4.4)
revision.text:
[[File:Dramatism Pentad.png|thumbnail|A diagram of the dramatistic pentad depicting Attitude as a derivative of Agent.]] The '''dramatistic pentad''' forms the core structure of [[dramatism]], a method for examining motivations that the renowned [[literary critic]] [[Kenneth Burke]] developed. Dramatism recommends the use of a [[metalinguistic]] approach to stories about human action that investigates the roles and uses of five [[rhetoric]]al elements common to all narratives, each of which is related to a question. These five rhetorical elements form the "dramatistic pentad." Burke argues that an evaluation of the relative emphasis that is given to each of the five elements by a human drama enables a determination of the motive for the behaviour of its [[Character (arts)|character]]s. A character's stress on one element over the others suggests their [[world view]].
Burke introduced the pentad in his 1945 book "A Grammar of Motives". Burke based his pentad on the scholastic hexameter which defines "questions to be answered in the treatment of a topic: Who, what, where, by what means, why, how, when".<ref>Burke, Kenneth. "A Grammar of Motives". University of California Press, 1969, p. 228</ref> Burke created the pentad by combining several of the categories in the scholastic hexameter. The result was a pentad that has the five categories of: act, scene, agent, agency, and purpose. Burke states, "The 'who' is obviously covered by agent. Scene covers the 'where' and the 'when'. The 'why' is purpose. 'How' and 'by what means' fall under agency. All that is left to take care of is act in our terms and 'what' in the scholastic formula".<ref>Burke, Kenneth. "A Grammar of Motives". University of California Press, 1969, p. 228.</ref>
The pentad also closely follows the journalistic '[[Five Ws]]': who, what, when, where, why. 'Who' maps to agent. 'What' maps to action. 'When' and 'Where' map to scene. 'Why' maps to purpose. There is no direct mapping from the Five Ws to the pentads category of agency but Geoff Hart states "Some authorities add a sixth question, “how”, to this list, but “how to” information generally fits under what, where, or when, depending on the nature of the information." <ref>"The Five Ws of Online Help". by Geoff Hart, TECHWR-L. Retrieved April 30, 2012.</ref>
==Rhetorical elements of the dramatistic pentad== The dramatistic pentad comprises the five rhetorical elements: Act, Scene, Agent, Agency, and Purpose. The “world views” listed below reflect the prominent schools of thought during Burke’s time, “without dismissing any of them," to read them "at once sympathetically and critically in relation to each other," and "in a wider context than any of them recognizes."<ref>{{cite book|last1=Fergusson|first1=Francis|title=Kenneth Burke's A Grammar of Motives|date=1957|publisher=Doubleday Anchor Books|location=NY|pages=193–204}}</ref>
===Act=== Act, which is associated with dramatic action verbs and answers the question "what?", is related to the world view of [[Philosophical realism|realism]]; What happened? What is the action? What is going on? What action; what thoughts? Burke defines the act as that which “names what took place, in thought or deed.” Since an act is likely composed of many separate actions, Burke states that “any verb, no matter how specific or general, that has connotations of consciousness or purpose falls under this category.”<ref name="A Grammar of Motives">{{cite journal|last1=Burke|first1=Kenneth|title=A Grammar of Motives|journal=The Rhetorical Tradition|date=2001|page=1298}}</ref>
===Scene=== Scene, which is associated with the [[Setting (fiction)|setting]] of an act and answers the questions "when?" and "where?", is related to the world view of [[materialism]] and minimal or non-existent [[free will]]. Burke defines the scene as “the background of an act, the situation in which it occurred.” <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Burke|first1=Kenneth|title=A Grammar of Motives|journal=The Rhetorical Tradition|date=2001|page=1301}}</ref>
===Agent=== Agent, which answers the question "by whom?", reflects the world view of [[philosophical idealism]]. Burke defines the agent as “what person or kind of person performed the act.” <ref name="A Grammar of Motives"/>
===Agency=== Agency (means), which is associated with the person or the organization that committed the deed and answers the question "how?", implies a [[Pragmatism|pragmatic]] point of view. Burke defines agency as “what instrument or instruments he used.”<ref name="A Grammar of Motives"/>
===Purpose=== Purpose, which is associated with meaning and answers the question "why?", indicates that the agent seeks unity through identification with an ultimate meaning of life. Reflects the world view of mysticism. Purpose is inextricably linked to the analysis of “Motive” which, derived from the title of A Grammar of Motives, is the main subject of its analysis. Since Purpose is both the subject of analysis and an element of the dramatistic pentad, it is not a common element to be included in a ratio.
==Ratios within the dramatistic pentad== In A Grammar of Motives, Burke provides a system of analysis for the Scene-Act ratio and the Scene-Agent ratio, though his analysis of ratios in the analysis of rhetoric is not limited to these. He states that, “The principles of dramatic consistency would lead one to expect such cases of overlap among the terms; but while being aware of them we should firmly fix in our minds such cases as afford a clear differentiation. Our terms leaning themselves towards merger and division, we are here trying to divide two of them while recognizing their possibilities of merger.” <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Burke|first1=Kenneth|title=A Grammar of Motives|journal=The Rhetorical Tradition|date=2001|page=1305}}</ref> Thus any two dramatistic elements can be analyzed in relation to each other, creating a ratio, and can produce individual, yet separate meanings which are equally valid. However, the rhetor’s selection of elements to compose a ratio should be scrutinized, as it can deflect attention away from or direct attention towards aspects of the rhetor’s desire.
This is what Burke calls the “Ubiquity of the Ratios,” claiming that the composition of ratios “are at the very centre of motivational assumptions,” <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Burke|first1=Kenneth|title=A Grammar of Motives|journal=The Rhetorical Tradition|date=2001|page=1307}}</ref> For example, “The maxim ‘terrain determines tactics’ is a strict localization of the scene-act ratio, with ‘terrain’ as the casuistic equivalent for ‘scene’ in a military calculus of motives, and ‘tactics’ as the corresponding ‘act.’"<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Burke|first1=Kenneth|title=A Grammar of Motives|journal=The Rhetorical Tradition|page=1308}}</ref> The analysis of a situation as a multi-faceted occurrence is central to Burke’s concept of ratios. Likewise, the substitution of a dramatistic element with another can change an interpretation of the motive, allowing the analyst to modify the ratio in order to highlight the importance of a specific factor. For example, “the resistance of the Russian armies to the Nazi invasion could be explained ‘scenically’ in terms of the Soviet political and economic structure; or one could use the act-agent ratio, attributing the power and tenacity to ‘Russian’ traits of character. However, in deriving the act from the scene, one would have to credit socialism as a major scenic factor, whereas a derivation of the act from agents would allow for a much more felicitous explanation from the standpoint of capitalist apologists.”<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Burke|first1=Kenneth|title=A Grammar of Motives|journal=The Rhetorical Tradition|date=2001|page=1310}}</ref>
The rhetor-agent also has a significant amount of power in crafting the perception of these ratios to their effect, “If an agent acts in keeping with his nature as an agent (act-agent ratio), he may change the nature of the scene accordingly (scene-act ratio) and thereby establish a state of unity between himself and his world (scene-agent ratio)."<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Burke|first1=Kenneth|title=A Grammar of Motives|journal=The Rhetorical Tradition|date=2001|page=1312}}</ref>
===Scene-Act ratio=== The scene, or the setting, will contain the act, or the what/actions. The way in which the agent interacts with the scene draws out specific analyses usually related to the atmosphere of the setting. While Burke states that, “It is a principle of drama that the nature of acts and agents should be consistent with the nature of the scene,” some “comic and grotesque works may deliberately set these elements at odds with one another, audiences make allowances for such liberty, which reaffirms the same principle of consistency in its very violation.”<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Burke|first1=Kenneth|title=A Grammar of Motives|journal=The Rhetorical Tradition|date=2001|page=1302}}</ref> This reflects the division of most plays into very literal “acts,” as the agents who construct the scene are very literally “acters” whose work is played against the backdrop of the scene.The actions that a person performs are interpreted through the setting or happenings.<ref name="Burke1978">Burke,Kenneth."Questions and Answers about the Pentad". National Council of Teachers of English, 1978, p. 332-333.</ref>
===Scene-Agent ratio=== A relationship between the agent (person) and the scene (place or setting). A scene can pose restrictions on the agent; in a narrative, the person and place should have some connection.<ref name="Burke1978" />
===Act-Agent ratio=== While requiring the scene to contain them, the agent does not contain the act. Burke states that, “the agent is an author of his acts,” which can “make him or remake him in accordance with their nature.”<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Burke|first1=Kenneth|title=A Grammar of Motives|journal=The Rhetorical Tradition|date=2001|page=1309}}</ref> This is one of the main principles that separates act and agent, producing a linked cycle which constructs the presentation of the agent’s identity.
==A sixth element== In A Grammar of Motives, Burke mentions that attitude is “a state of mind,”<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Burke|first1=Kenneth|title=A Grammar of Motives|journal=The Rhetorical Situation|date=2001|page=1302}}</ref> remaining exterior from the pentad, as it is often “a preparation for an act, which would make it kind of symbolic act, or incipient act. But in its character as a state of mind that may or may not lead to an act, it is clearly classified under the head of agent.”. Burke also refers to attitude as a variation of agency.<ref name=Anderson2010 /> Prior to 1969 the term attitude is placed under agency, act or agent and is not considered a sixth element.<ref>Burke, Kenneth. "A Grammar of Motives". University of California Press, 1969, p. 476</ref> In 1969, Burke places attitude as a new sixth element, yet he does not refer to the pentad as a hexad.<ref name="Anderson2010">Anderson, F. D., & Althouse, M. T. (2010). “Five Fingers or Six? Pentad or Hexad”. KB Journal, 6(2). Retrieved October 27, 2014.</ref> Attitude is defined as "the preparation for an act, which would make it a kind of symbolic act, or incipient act." The attitude, like the agency, would answer the “how?”.<ref>Burke, Kenneth. (1965). “Permanence and Change”. 1954. Indianapolis: Bobbs-Merrill.</ref> There is still some uncertainty over whether attitude is an additional element, and thus makes the dramatistic pentad a hexad, or if it is still a sub-element of the original pentad.<ref name="Anderson2010" /> While Burke has never directly stated that the pentad is a hexad, he has admitted that the addition of attitude to the pentad is similar to gaining “another soul” or an “extra existence.”<ref>{{cite journal|last1=King|first1=Andrew|title=Disciplining The Master: Finding the Via Media for Kenneth Burke|journal=American Communication Journal|date=2001|volume=4|issue=2}}</ref> Scholars have read this as Burke’s desire not to “dispose of” ambiguity, but rather to “study and clarify the resources of ambiguity.”<ref name=Anderson2010 /> As a result, many diagrams of the pentad depict attitude as a derivative of agent.
==Notes== <ref name="5W">"The Five Ws of Online Help Systems" by Geoff Hart, TECHWR-L. Retrieved April 30, 2012.[http://www.geoff-hart.com/articles/2002/fivew.htm]</ref> {{reflist}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Dramatistic Pentad}} [[Category:Literary criticism]] [[Category:Narratology]] [[Category:Plot (narrative)]] [[Category:Rhetoric]]

revision.comment: Fix links to [[Adventure]] (via [[WP:JWB]])
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=October 2017}} {{Infobox video game |title = Désiré |image = Désiré Cover Art.png |caption = Cover art |developer = Sylvain Seccia |publisher = Sylvain Seccia |designer = Sylvain Seccia |artist = Sébastien Vallart
Antoine Gouy
Maxime Morvan |composer = Loïk Brédolèse |released = May 10, 2016 |genre = [[Adventure game|Adventure]] |modes = [[Single-player]] |platforms = [[Mac OS|Macintosh]]
[[Microsoft Windows|Windows]]
[[Steam (software)|Steam]]
[[Android (operating system)|Android]]
[[iOS]]}} '''Désiré''' is a French [[indie video game|indie]] [[Adventure game#Point-and-click adventure games|point-and-click adventure video game]] by Sylvain Seccia, it was published in 2016. The game is about the titular character, Désiré, an [[Achromatopsia|achromatic]] boy who only sees black and white, and the player guides him in 4 various parts of his life. The game contains themes such as [[sexuality]], [[bullying]], [[pedophilia]], [[zoophilia]], [[suicide]], [[Depression (mood)|depression]], [[morality]], [[feminism]], [[BDSM]] and criticism of aspects of modern society such as [[capitalism]] and [[materialism]]. ==Plot== The game begins with a cutscene of a young Désiré who is asked by his [[kindergarten]] teacher why he hasn't drawn the sun like the other children, he replies that he has never seen the sun, since it "is always night in his head". The actual game starts on a beach in 1992, where a young Désiré wants to cast a "love spell" to a classmate he has a crush on. The player directs Désiré in all his actions, and can pick up objects, talk to various characters and explore the world. After successfully burrying a box with an egg, which has the name of Désiré's crush on it, in it, the game continues to the next chapter. Désiré, who lives in the suburbs of [[Lyon]] with his parents and brother Bruno, is advised by an old man, who is apparently imaginary as other characters imply, to stand up against a boy who bullies him at school, David. Désiré plots to catch David, who has an addiction to [[masturbating]], in the act and distribute pictures of it around the school. After successfully doing this, David and Désiré are both expelled from school. The next chapter starts in 2003, Désiré, now an adult man living in Paris, is informed that his company is firing him because they are outsourcing part of its operations. Désiré is in love with Elma, who doesn't seem to return the feeling, and he promises her a gig at a restaurant in an attempt to woo her. After successfully doing this, Elma doesn't show up at the day of the gig, and a heartbroken Désiré comes to believe that it is better not to love. In 2011, Désiré has discarded love and instead visits brothels to satisfy his desires. The chapter begins with a dream or hallucination of Désiré standing before a brothel which appears as a giant woman's genital area. Désiré also visits, Élodie, one of his friends who is in love with her dog Rocco. He decides to visit another friend, Damien and recruits the help of Andy, another friend, to find him after discovering threatening letters from Damien's neighbour. Eventually, it turns out Damien committed [[suicide]], and it is also revealed he was a pedophile, but never actually acted on it. The chapter ends with Désiré talking to a hallucination of an obese man who tries to convince him to stop changing society, however corrupt it might be, and just accept everything. The final chapter starts in 2020. Désiré has been living a village in Congo for 2 years, but wants to return to France and find the manuscript which an old sailor give him when he was a child. His parents gave the manuscript to a charity, and Désiré returns to [[Lyon]] in search of it. A clue in a secondhand shop gives him a lead, but the shop salesman, who is revealed to be David, confronts Désiré, who is forced to beat up the former. Désiré tracks down the manuscript to a small village. He finds a young girl, Léa, alone on the streets and reveals her grandfather is Martin Lacour, an antique collector who currently owns the manuscript. Désiré accompanies Léa back home, and Lacour reluctantly allows Désiré to read the manuscript. After realizing it is the real one, he steals it from Lacour's safe and reads it in the local church. Désiré is now able to see colors, and is ecstatic, but can't bring himself to steal it and decides to return it to Léa, who thanks him. The chapters ends with Désiré hallucinating an apparition of [[Jesus]], who claims Désiré is afraid of change and gave the manuscript away for that reason. The game ends with Désiré finally accepting the world as it ends, yet feeling condemned to live while pursuing his path. ==Reception== Reception to the game on [[Steam (software)|Steam]] was mixed.{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161216015139/http://store.steampowered.com/app/399700|title=The Steam page of the game on the Internet Archive}} It was later removed from the Steam Store because the author had created multiple accounts to improve the game's rating. The French gaming website Joypad gave it a positive review.{{cite web|url=http://joypad.fr/test-desire-point-click-pour-joueurs-avertis/|title=DÉSIRÉ – POINT & CLICK POUR JOUEURS AVERTIS}} The game was notable enough to receive coverage on a TV report of [[La Une]].{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q7QAL6Y2nHU|title=La Une TV report on Désiré}} The game won Best Mobile Game and Best Game Audio at the Tel Aviv Indie Game Awards 2016,{{cite web|url=http://indieprize.org/kyiv2017/#telaviv2016-winners|title=Indie Showcase}} and Best Game Narrative in the Asia Indie Game Awards 2016. It also won Best Game Audio in the Évry Games City Awards 2016. ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Désiré (video game)}} [[Category:Android (operating system) games]] [[Category:Video games developed in France]] [[Category:2016 video games]] [[Category:IOS games]] [[Category:MacOS games]] [[Category:Video games set in France]] [[Category:Point-and-click adventure games]] [[Category:Windows games]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox Newspaper | name = EU Jacksonville | image = | caption = | type = Monthly entertainment magazine | format = [[Tabloid (newspaper format)|Tabloid]] | foundation = 1976 | ceased publication = | owners = [[Independent business|Independent]] | publisher = Will Henley | chiefeditor = | circulation = | headquarters = [[Jacksonville, Florida]] | ISSN = | oclc = | website = [http://www.eujacksonville.com eujacksonville.com] }} '''''EU Jacksonville''''' is a monthly entertainment magazine published in [[Jacksonville, Florida]]. It contains feature reporting and entertainment and cultural guides for Jacksonville and the [[Northeast Florida]] region.
==History== The publication was founded as the ''Southeast Entertainer'' in 1976 by Jacksonville businessman and musician Tony Trotti. Originally an occasional publication, Trotti made it a [[Weekly newspaper|weekly]] in the 1980s and changed the name to ''First Coast Entertainer'', leaving his job as vice president of George Washington Life Insurance to work on the paper. In addition to covering Jacksonville's entertainment scene, the paper had a promotion arrangement with film companies to give out free movie tickets to readers.<ref name=Kerr>{{cite news |title= First Coast Entertainer owner dies at 59 |author= Jessie-Lynne Kerr|url= http://jacksonville.com/tu-online/stories/031803/met_12032471.shtml |newspaper= [[The Florida Times-Union]] |date= March 18, 2003 |accessdate=July 28, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.metrojacksonville.com/article/2012-jul-a-brief-history-of-jacksonville-music-news4jax |title= A Brief History of Jacksonville Music |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= July 7, 2012 |website= [[metrojacksonville.com]] |publisher= |accessdate=July 28, 2013}}</ref><ref name=Henley>{{cite web |url= http://www.eujacksonville.com/urbanjax.htm |title= EU talks with Urban Jacksonville Blog |author= Rachel Best Henley |date= 2007 |website= eujacksonville.com| publisher= EU Jacksonville |accessdate=July 28, 2013}}</ref>
Trotti died in 2003, and the ''Entertainer'' briefly stopped publication. Associate publisher Will Henley started a similar weekly called ''Entertaining U'' or ''EU Jacksonville'', and then bought and absorbed the ''Entertainer'', retaining most of its staff. ''EU'' underwent several format shifts and redesigns during the 2000s.<ref name=Kerr/><ref name=Henley/> In March 2008 it shifted to its present monthly tabloid format with expanded web offerings.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.eujacksonville.com/pages/03-08/index.html |title= A letter from eu |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |date= March 2008 |website= eujacksonville.com |publisher= |accessdate=July 28, 2013}}</ref> The paper includes feature stories as well as reviews of films, music, entertainment and nightlife in the region.<ref>{{cite book |title= Insiders' Guide to Jacksonville, 3rd Edition|last= Reiss|first= Sarah W. |authorlink= |coauthors= |year= 2009 |publisher= Globe Pequot |location= |isbn= 0-7627-5032-4|page= 218 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=rlHWoqDYZHkC&pg=PA218&dq=%22Entertaining+U%22+jacksonville.com&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Npf1UazdNK-y4APU3YDwAw&ved=0CFMQ6AEwAg#v=onepage&q=%22Entertaining%20U%22%20jacksonville.com&f=false|accessdate= July 28, 2013}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.eujacksonville.com/ ''EU Jacksonville'']
{{Jacksonville}}

{{Use Indian English|date=November 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2014 }} {{Infobox television season | show_name = Fear Factor: Khatron Ke Khiladi | pre_season_qualifier = | season_qualifier = | season_number = 7 | bgcolour = #00FF00 | image = | image_alt = | caption = | starring = {{Plainlist| * [[Rohit Shetty]] }} | country = India | num_episodes = 21 | network = [[Colors TV]] | first_aired = {{start date|df=yes|2016|1|30}} | last_aired = {{end date|df=yes|2016|4|3}} | episode_list = | prev_season = [[Fear Factor: Khatron Ke Khiladi 6|Season 6]] | next_season = [[Fear Factor: Khatron Ke Khiladi 8|Season 8]] }} The '''seventh season''' of '''''[[Fear Factor: Khatron Ke Khiladi]]''''' which is an [[India]]n [[Reality television|reality]] and [[Stunt|stunt television series]] commenced on 30 January 2016 and is broadcast on [[Colors TV]]. The name of the season is titled as ''Khatron Ke Khiladi: Kabhi Peeda, Kabhi Keeda''. The series is aired on every Saturday and Sunday nights. The series is produced by [[Endemol India]] of Deepak Dhar.{{cite news|url=http://www.indiawest.com/entertainment/television/arjun-kapoor-s-fear-factor---khatron-ke-khiladi/article_59bdd3ac-c552-11e5-a033-07ec99ddc7d3.html|title=Arjun Kapoor’s ‘Fear Factor - Khatron Ke Khiladi’ Season 7 to Premiere Jan. 30|newspaper=India West|date=28 January 2016|accessdate=28 January 2016}} The winner of the season is [[Siddharth Shukla]]. The season is hosted by [[Arjun Kapoor]] and is shot in [[Argentina]].{{cite news|url=http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ians/khatron-ke-khiladi-packs-more-power-for-new-season-115103000707_1.html|title='Khatron Ke Khiladi' packs more power for new season|newspaper=[[Business Standard]]|date=30 October 2015|accessdate=4 November 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://indianexpress.com/photos/entertainment-gallery/khatron-ke-khiladi-7-arjun-kapoor-is-the-new-host-sidharth-jay-faisal-among-contestants/|title=‘Khatron Ke Khiladi 7’: Arjun Kapoor is the new host, Sidharth, Jay, Faisal among contestants|newspaper=[[The Indian Express]]|date=30 October 2015|accessdate=4 November 2015}}{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/tv/news/hindi/Khatron-Ke-Khiladi-Chills-Thrills-Much-More/photostory/49617154.cms|title=Khatron Ke Khiladi: Chills, Thrills & Much More|newspaper=[[The Times of India]]|date=1 November 2015|accessdate=4 November 2015}} ==Contestants== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="text-align:center; |- ! colspan="2"|Name ! revision.comment: Correcting a mistake in code (missing >)
revision.text:
'''Fire on the Mountain''' is a game played by children in Tanzania.<ref>{{cite book |title=Games we should play in school: a revealing analysis of the social forces in the classroom and a practical approach to understanding and shaping them including over 55 dynamic and fun social games |last=Aycox |first=Frank |author2=Frank Alexander |pages=69–70 |year=1985 |publisher=Front Row Experience |isbn=978-0-915256-16-7 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Learning about human behavior through active games |last=Cratty |first=Bryant J. |pages=197–199 |year=1974 |publisher=[[Prentice-Hall]] |isbn=978-0-13-527473-6 }}</ref>
This game can be played about people of all ages. You need at least 5 players for this game to work. The aim of the game is to be the player who stays in the game the longest..
* To start the game, first choose a player to be the leader. * Players think of a 'key word'. It can be any word or a name. For example, 'cheese'. * All players lie on their backs. * The leader shouts out "Fire on the mountain!" All the players respond with "Fire!" but stay lying down. Then the leader shouts out "Fire on the river!" Again the players reply with "Fire" but do not jump up. This continues on with the leader changing the last word of the phrase. He tries to think of as many different places for the fire. * The leader is able to shout out the key word at any time, as part of the phrases or in between them. When he shouts it out the players must all jump up. The last one to jump up is out of the game. * The winner is the player who stays in the game the longest.
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:African games]] [[Category:Children's games]]

revision.comment: Added to categories
revision.text:
[[File:FYC set.JPG|thumb|right|200px|A "For Your Consideration" promotional box set from [[HBO]]]] '''For Your Consideration''' is a heading frequently used in [[advertisement]]s in [[entertainment]] [[entertainment industry|trade]] publications such as ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]], [[Backstage (magazine)|Backstage]],'' and ''[[The Hollywood Reporter]]''. They are specifically directed towards members of awards voting groups in the entertainment industry, like the [[Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences]] that annually presents the [[Academy Awards]] celebrating the best in [[motion picture]]s, or the [[Academy of Television Arts & Sciences]] which presents the [[Primetime Emmy Award]]s for [[television]].
Each year, the major [[movie studio]]s, and to a lesser extent their affiliated television studios and the [[television network]]s, spend large sums of money on For Your Consideration ads extolling the alleged virtues of their films or programs released over the previous year.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Dark Knight's For Your Consideration Ads in Variety|url=http://www.firstshowing.net/2008/11/22/the-dark-knights-for-your-consideration-ads-in-variety/|author=Billington, Alex|date=November 22, 2008|publisher=Firstshowing.net}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=More Variety Covers, Less Variety on the Cover|url=http://carpetbagger.blogs.nytimes.com/tag/for-your-consideration-ads/|publisher=New York Times|date=December 19, 2008}}</ref> In recent years, these ads have begun to appear online at websites popular with voting members of the applicable academies.
In the mid-1990s, in addition to print advertising, networks began releasing special editions of their programming to allow voters a chance to review the content before casting their votes.<ref>{{cite book|title=Billboard|date=June 11, 1994|author=Fitzpatrick, Eileen|page=72}}</ref> Mailing [[DVD]] sets to Emmy voters became a common practice; clever packaging has been credited with garnering Emmy nominations for otherwise forgotten programs, and the ever-increasing complexity of mailers has been likened to an [[arms race]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Will Emmy notice fancy packages?|url=http://www.variety.com/article/VR1117965956.html?categoryid=2583&ref=ra&cs=1|work=Variety|date=May 29, 2007|author=Gervich, Chad}}</ref> Some studios, however, have begun moving their content online to lessen environmental impact and avoid the high cost of postage.<ref>{{cite news|title=TV networks scaling back on DVD mailers|publisher=Los Angeles Times|author=Collins, Scott|date=June 4, 2008|url=http://theenvelope.latimes.com/awards/sag/env-en-channel4-2008jun04,0,1910897.story}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=TV networks, studios get creative for Emmy season|publisher=Reuters|date=May 19, 2008|author=Nordyke, Kimberly|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/televisionNews/idUSN1941676520080520}}</ref> Online applications have their own benefits: In 2009 [[Showtime (TV network)|Showtime]] launched a password-protected site that allowed voters to download [[streaming video]] of "For Your Consideration" programming to mobile devices.<ref>{{cite news|title=Showtime Emmy campaign goes mobile|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/pressRelease/idUS159586+04-Mar-2009+PRN20090304|date=March 4, 2009 | work=Reuters}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Advertising slogans]] [[Category:Academy Awards]] [[Category:Primetime Emmy Awards]] [[Category:English phrases]] [[Category:Film advertising material]]
