{{about||the Krazy Kat film|The Medicine Show|the Dream Syndicate album|Medicine Show (album)}} [[Image:Ringwood Il Medicine show1.JPG|thumb|250px|right|A reenactment of a medicine show in [[Ringwood, Illinois]]]] '''Medicine shows''' were touring acts (traveling by truck, horse, or wagon teams) that peddled "miracle cure" [[patent medicine]]s and other products between various entertainments. They developed from European [[Charlatan|mountebank]] shows and were common in the United States in the nineteenth century, especially in the [[American Old West|Old West]] (though some continued until [[World War II]]).<ref name="Step Right Up">{{cite book|last1=McNamara|first1=Brooks|title=Step Right Up|date=1976}}</ref> They usually promoted "miracle [[elixir]]s" (sometimes referred to as [[snake oil]]), which, it was claimed, had the ability to cure disease, smooth wrinkles, remove stains, prolong life or cure any number of common ailments. Most shows had their own patent medicine (these medicines were for the most part unpatented but took the name to sound official). Entertainments often included a [[freak show]], a [[flea circus]], [[musical ensemble|musical act]]s, [[magic (illusion)|magic trick]]s, jokes, or [[storytelling]]. Each show was run by a man posing as a doctor who drew the crowd with a monologue. The entertainers, such as acrobats, musclemen, magicians, dancers, ventriloquists, exotic performers, and [[Exhibition shooting|trick shots]], kept the audience engaged until the salesman sold his medicine.
==History== {{Refimprove section|date=November 2016}}
===Origins=== [[File:Clark Stanley's Snake Oil Liniment.png|thumb|Advertisement for Clark Stanley's [[snake oil|Snake Oil]] [[Liniment]]]] While showmen pitching miraculous cures have been around since classical times,<ref name="Anderson-1">{{cite book |last= Anderson |first= Ann |year= 2000 |title= Snake Oil, Hustlers and Hambones: The American Medicine Show |publisher= McFarland |location= Jefferson, NC |page= 1 |isbn= 0786408006}}</ref> the advent of mixed performance and medicine sales in western culture originated during the [[Dark Ages (historiography)|Dark Ages]] in Europe after circuses and theatres were banned and performers had only the marketplace or patrons for support.<ref name="Anderson-1"/> [[Charlatan|Mountebank]]s traveled through small towns and large cities, selling miraculous elixirs by offering small street shows and miraculous cures.<ref name="Step Right Up"/> Itinerant [[peddler]]s of dubious medicines appeared in the American colonies before 1772, when legislation prohibiting their activities was enacted. Increasingly elaborate performances were developed to appeal to a largely rural population.
===Nineteenth century=== Over the course of the nineteenth century, traveling mountebanks gave way to more polished medicine shows, which availed themselves of a burgeoning patent medicine industry. At least 1,500 patent medicines were recorded by 1858, affording enterprising drifters a specific product to sell.<ref name=Anderson-1 /> These "medicines" seldom treated the specific symptoms of an illness, instead relying on stimulants or other drugs to produce a pleasurable effect. [[Alcohol]], [[opium]] and [[cocaine]] were typical ingredients, and their addictive qualities provided an additional incentive for consumers to continue buying them, while their supposed medicinal benefit afforded a sufficient excuse. By 1900, the patent medicine industry was an $80 million business. Also contributing to the rise of the medicine show was the expansion of the advertising industry, through which shows were able to procure inexpensive posters, fliers, handbills, and other merchandising to promote their products.<ref name="Step Right Up"/> Other forms of advertising included the use of memorable [[jingle]]s, sensational testimonials, and [[fear mongering#in marketing|scare tactics]].
Medicine shows combined various forms of popular entertainment with sales pitches from a self-proclaimed "doctor" who sold an astounding cure-all medicine or device. Shows played either outdoors from a wagon, platform or tent, or indoors in a theatre or opera hall. Admission was usually free or nominal. Pitchmen would make grandiose claims about their product’s efficacy, sometimes planting testimonials in the audience. The speaker's goal was to create a need, or fear, then offer his unique medicine as the only cure. Alternating entertainment with sales pitches wore down the audience's resistance, until the crowd was saturated with a desire for the product. The show would continue to run as many days as possible, then move on to the next town. A show might remain in a given location between one night and six weeks, depending on how the troupe behaved itself.
Medicine shows often brought entertainment to rural communities that might not have any other sort of performances for years at a time. Whatever the quality of the medical advice, spectators got their money's worth from the free entertainment. Some shows followed circuits covering the entire United States, though most shows focused on the rural midwest and south, where the inhabitants were considered particularly gullible.{{cn|date=November 2018}}
==Hamlin's Wizard Oil Company and Kickapoo Indian Medicine Company== The two largest, most successful American medicine shows were [[Hamlin’s Wizard Oil Company]], founded in Chicago by John and Lysander Hamlin, and the [[Kickapoo Indian Medicine Company]], founded in 1881 by Charles Bigelow and John Healey.<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.pantagraph.com/news/local/indian-medicine-shows-once-popular-entertainment/article_3fa0072d-764a-57ef-b6ea-91afd32021d6.html |title=‘Indian’ medicine shows once popular entertainment |newspaper= [[The Pantagraph]] |date= 2016-03-20 |accessdate= 2016-04-11 |last= Kemp |first= Bill}}</ref> Hamlin’s Wizard Oil Company troupes travelled in specially designed wagons, with built-in organs and space for musical performers. Their appeal was clean, moral, musical entertainment for the whole family. Part of their advertising included songsters, or small booklets of song lyrics and Wizard Oil advertising.<ref name="Step Right Up"/> The Kickapoo Indian Medicine Company created traveling shows based around sham Indian presentational ceremonies, such as war dances and marriages. "Representatives" of the Kickapoo tribe translated for the Indians and sold Sagwa, the most famous patent medicine. The company also presented other forms of entertainment, such as vaudeville shows, trained dog acts, dances, and acrobatics.
==20th century== As reliable commercial pharmaceuticals were produced on an industrial level in the early 20th century, the reputation of and market for home remedies began to dwindle, and medicine shows came to rely ever more on their entertainment value. But as America's population became less rural and more urbanized, the availability of other forms of entertainment, such as [[film|motion pictures]], [[vaudeville]] and later [[radio]], led to the gradual disappearance of the traveling medicine show. By the 1930s few such companies continued to tour in the United States. Even fewer shows endured the economic and social upheaval of the [[Great Depression]] and [[World War II]]. Those that survived into the 1950s found themselves competing with [[television]] and came to be regarded as relics of an earlier, more innocent era. This novelty, far more than the availability of the remedies peddled, provided the chief support for the last of the traveling medicine shows.
===The Hadacol Caravan=== One of the most famous of the 20th-century traveling shows was the Hadacol Caravan, sponsored by [[Louisiana]] State Senator [[Dudley J. LeBlanc]] and his LeBlanc Corporation, makers of the dubious [[patent medicine]]/[[vitamin|vitamin tonic]] [[Hadacol]], known for both its alleged curative powers and its high alcohol content. The stage show, which ran throughout the [[Deep South]] in the 1940s with great publicity, featured a number of notable music acts and [[Cinema of the United States|Hollywood]] celebrities and promoted Hadacol, which was sold during [[intermission]] and after the show. Admission to the show was paid in [[boxtop]]s of the vitamin tonic, sold in stores throughout the southern United States. The Caravan came to a sudden halt in 1951, when the Hadacol enterprise fell apart in a financial scandal.
===Chief Thundercloud and Peg Leg Sam=== One of the last great medicine shows had its swan song in the summer of 1972, when the two-man show of Chief Thundercloud (pitchman Leo Kahdot, a [[Potawatomi]] from [[Oklahoma]])<ref>{{cite news |title= Herbs! Roots! Bark! Leaves! |last= Kruesi |first= Margaret |url= https://www.loc.gov/folklife/news/news-text-fall2004.html |magazine= Folklife Center News |date=Fall 2004 |volume= 26 |issue= 4 |pages= 5–7 |publisher= [[American Folklife Center]], [[Library of Congress]] |accessdate= 2010-01-22}}</ref> and [[Peg Leg Sam]] (harmonicist-singer-comedian Arthur Jackson) played at a carnival in [[Pittsboro, North Carolina]]. It was the last show of the year for them; Kahdot died that winter.<ref>{{cite news |title= Born for Hard Luck (1976) Directed by Tom Davenport |type= movie review |series= 13 More Essential Southern Documentaries |last= Ridley |first= Jim |url= http://oxfordamericanmag.com/content.cfm?ArticleID=169& |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20070621014457/http://oxfordamericanmag.com/content.cfm?ArticleID=169& |archivedate= 2007-06-21 |magazine= [[Oxford American]] |issue= 56 |accessdate= 2010-01-22}}</ref>
==="Doc" Scott’s Last Real Old Time Medicine Show=== Perhaps the last of the medicine shows was run by [[Ramblin' Tommy Scott|Tommy Scott]], who staged as many as three hundred shows per year until about 1990. As a teenager in the 1930s, Scott joined the ''"Doc" Chambers Medicine Show'', established by M. F. Chambers in the late nineteenth century. Scott sang, played guitar, performed [[ventriloquism]] and [[blackface]] acts, and pitched Chambers's Herb-O-Lac herbal [[laxative]]. When Chambers retired in the late 1930s, Scott took charge of the show, performing for many years with his wife, Mary, and his sidekick, Gaines Blevins, known as "Old Bleb". Scott's daughter, Sandra, performed in the show as a singer, bass player, and acrobat, and from the 1960s onward managed the business end of the show. Herb-O-Lac eventually gave way to a [[menthol]]ated skin [[liniment]], which Scott dubbed Snake Oil. For decades, the show toured arenas and senior centers as ''"Doc" Scott's Last Real Old Time Medicine Show''. From the 1960s to the 1980s, the show also solicited donations for charitable organizations such as the [[Lions Clubs International|Lions Club]] and the [[Optimist International|Optimist Club]].<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2013/10/15/arts/music/tommy-scott-singer-songwriter-and-pitchman-dies-at-96.html?hpw |title= Tommy Scott, Country Singer with a Traveling Medicine Show, Dies at 96 |newspaper= [[The New York Times|New York Times]] |date= 2013-10-14 |accessdate= 2014-01-04 |last= Yardley |first= William}}</ref>
==In popular culture== The 1930 film ''[[The Medicine Man (1930 film)|The Medicine Man]]'' mixes comedy and melodrama with a medicine show coming into a small town.
In the 1932 [[Fleischer Studios]] cartoon ''[[Betty Boop, M.D.]]'', Betty, Bimbo and Koko are the owners of a traveling medicine show. They are selling "Jippo", an all-purpose health tonic, which appears to be water pumped from a fire hydrant, although consuming it has a number of bizarre effects.
In the 1933 [[Krazy Kat]] cartoon ''[[The Medicine Show]]'', Krazy runs a medicine show where he performs some acts and sells bottled liquids which have a variety of uses.
[[James Thurber]]'s eponymous "Doc Marlowe" (published in ''Let Your Mind Alone!'', in 1937) is a retired [[snake oil]] salesman in a traveling show, later selling the product as ''Blackhawk Liniment''. In a typical Thurber twist, Marlowe cheats in a small way at cards and in other games of chance, but his massages with snake-oil (a harmless but expensive preparation) are in fact highly effective.
In the 1949 film ''[[The Inspector General (film)|The Inspector General]]'', the character played by [[Danny Kaye]] works for a medicine show, selling "Yakov's Golden Elixir".
Several modern musical acts have named themselves after this old-time phenomenon, including [[Old Crow Medicine Show]], [[Dr. West's Medicine Show and Junk Band]], [http://www.moondogmedicineshow.com/ Moondog Medicine Show], [[Dr. Hook & The Medicine Show]] and [[MV & EE|MV & EE Medicine Show]]. The name was also used in the titles of [[The Dream Syndicate]]'s album ''[[Medicine Show (album)|Medicine Show]]'', [[Big Audio Dynamite]]'s song "Medicine Show", [[Moxy Früvous]]'s song "The Incredible Medicine Show", and [[The Band]]'s song "[[Stage Fright (album)|W.S. Walcott Medicine Show]]". Throughout 2010 and 2011, the hip hop artist [[Madlib]] released a 12-part mix series with the title "[[Madlib Medicine Show]]".
[[Science fiction]] author [[Orson Scott Card]] titled his online sci-fi journal "The [[Intergalactic Medicine Show]]".
British comedy trio [[The Goodies]] perform a scene as part of "The Goodies Traveling Medicine Show" in the episode of [[The Goodies (TV series)|their TV series]] entitled "[[Hospital For Hire]]". The scene includes a planted shill ([[Tim Brooke-Taylor]]) being pulled from the audience to 'prove' that the mystery elixir cured all ailments.
In [[Rockstar Games|Rockstar's]] video game ''[[Red Dead Redemption]]'', one of the main characters plays the role of an early 20th-century hustler peddling what John Marston refers to as snake oil.
"[[Your Song]]", by [[Elton John]], also mentions a man who makes "potions in a traveling show".
In 1970 two original members of [[The Open Theater]], Barbara Vann and James Barbosa, founded [[Medicine Show Theatre Ensemble]] also in New York. It moved around a number of times in its early years, having permanent performing spaces in 14 different locations until finally settling on West 52nd Street, where it remains today. Its work has consisted of new plays, original adaptations of classic books, reconstructions of classic musicals (especially those by [[Cole Porter]]) which were thought to have been lost, and clever adaptations of famous works, like inserting Cole Porter songs into Shakespeare plays and turning them into musical comedies.
On the 1974 album ''[[Everything You Know Is Wrong]]'' by the comedy troupe [[The Firesign Theatre]], the recording's narrator plays a wire recording of "Dr. Firesign's" medicine show, in which "Professor Archer" promotes "Chief Dancing Knockout's Pyramid Pushover Paste" and "Don Brouhaha's Inca Hell-Oil Tonic". Archer and his assistant prepare and ingest an [[hallucinogen]]ic potion with these ingredients which leads to an encounter with an Indian [[shaman]]. The entertainment consists of a play parodying ''[[Uncle Tom's Cabin]]''.
The song "[[Gypsys, Tramps & Thieves]]", performed by [[Cher]], is about a girl who was "born in the wagon of a traveling show". Her father would sell bottles of [[snake oil]] medicine called "Doctor Good".
The music video for the [[Michael Jackson]] and [[Paul McCartney]] song "[[Say, Say, Say]]" shows McCartney, [[Linda McCartney|his wife]], and Jackson performing a traditional medicine show.
In the "Grampa vs. Sexual Inadequacy" episode of ''[[The Simpsons]]'', [[Homer Simpson|Homer]] and [[Grampa Simpson]] travel across country, giving medicine shows for their aphrodisiac, "Simpson and Son's Tonic".
Performing as medicine pitchman J. Phineas Flusterbeck, magician Mark Nilsen presents shows based on the old medicine shows. He pitches "Blue Root Elixir", which (according to a fabricated biography) "restored his confidence in the gullibility of the American public".
Magician [[Whit Haydn|"Pop" Haydn]] models his magic shows after old-time medicine shows, complete with the selling of several products such as "Pop Haydn's Miracle Oil", which he claims to have received from "[[Placebo]] Indians".
The 1977 live-action/animated musical film ''[[Pete's Dragon (1977 film)|Pete's Dragon]]'' features a medicine showman called Dr. Terminus (played by [[Jim Dale]]), and local townspeople being first skeptical, then duped, by his claimed healing abilities.
== See also == * [[Snake oil]] * [[Patent medicine]] * [[Quackery]]
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==Bibliography== * Agnew, Jeremy. ''Entertainment in the Old West: Theater, Music, Circuses, Medicine Shows, Prizefighting and Other Popular Amusements''. Jefferson, N.C: McFarland & Company, Inc., Publishers, 2011. Print. * Anderson, Ann. ''Snake Oil, Hustlers and Hambones: The American Medicine Show''. Jefferson: McFarland & Company, 2000. Print. * McNamara, Brooks. ''Step Right up''. 1st ed. Garden City, N.Y: Doubleday, 1976. Print.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Medicine Show}} [[Category:Entertainment in the United States]] [[Category:Variety shows]] [[Category:Patent medicines]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 2 sources and tagging 0 as dead. #IABot (v2.0beta10) ([[User:Smasongarrison|Smasongarrison]])
revision.text:
{{Infobox company | name = North Carolina Film Office | logo = FlimNC seal.png | logo_size = 250px | type = Government Agency | foundation = 1980 | location = [[Raleigh, North Carolina]] | key_people = Guy Gaster, Director | industry = Film | num_employees = 4 | homepage = http://www.ncfilm.com }}
The '''North Carolina Film Office''', originally called the "North Carolina Film Commission," is a member of the [[Association of Film Commissioners International]].<ref>[http://www.afci.org/wwwapps/profile.ami?workingSearchKeyword=north%20carolina&workingCommissionID=4605 "North Carolina Film Office"], ''Association of Film Commissioners International'', Retrieved 2007-11-19.</ref>
==History== <!-- [[WP:Citing IMDb]] --> Founded in 1980 by Governor [[Jim Hunt|James B. Hunt]], the office was [[Film commission|commissioned]] to help facilitate and provide a base of operation for [[North Carolina|North Carolina's]] burgeoning film industry. Governor Hunt appointed William "Bill" Arnold to lead the office.<ref name="ncfilm1">[http://www.ncfilm.com/about-us.html "About Us"], ''North Carolina Film Office'', Retrieved 2008-02-15.</ref> In 1984, producer [[Dino De Laurentiis]] created [[De Laurentiis Entertainment Group]]. He built and based a studio complex (now [[EUE/Screen Gems]] <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.screengemsstudios.com/ |title=EUE/Screen Gems |publisher=Screengemsstudios.com |date= |accessdate=2013-08-19}}</ref>) in [[Wilmington, North Carolina]]. The area quickly became one of the busiest production centers for film and television east of Hollywood. The North Carolina Film Office was created during a time when new technology, audience demand for location authenticity, and Hollywood’s need for lower production costs were driving filmmakers to search distant sites throughout the United States for fresh places to make movies.<ref name="ncfilm1"/>
With Bill Arnold leading, the North Carolina Film Commission witnessed a dramatic increase in production during the 1980s and the 1990s. Notable films during this time include: ''[[The Color Purple (1985 film)|The Color Purple]]'' (1985),<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0088939/locations The Color Purple (1985) - Filming Locations - IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''[[Dirty Dancing]]'' (1987),<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0092890/locations Dirty Dancing (1987) - Filming Locations - IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''[[Bull Durham]]'' (1988),<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0094812/locations Bull Durham (1988) - Filming Locations - IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''[[Days of Thunder]]'' (1990),<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0099371/locations Days of Thunder (1990) - Filming Locations - IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''[[Sleeping with the Enemy (1991 film)|Sleeping with the Enemy]]'' (1991),<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0102945/locations Sleeping with the Enemy (1991) - Filming Locations - IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''[[The Last of the Mohicans (1992 film)|Last of the Mohicans]]'' (1992),<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0104691/locations The Last of the Mohicans (1992) - Filming Locations - IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''[[The Fugitive (1993 film)|The Fugitive]]'' (1993),<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0106977/locations The Fugitive (1993) - Filming Locations - IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> and ''[[The Crow (1994 film)|The Crow]]'' (1994).<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0109506/locations The Crow (1994) - Filming Locations - IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> In 1998 Wilmington, NC became the home of [[The WB Television Network|the WB's]] critically acclaimed television network series ''[[Dawson's Creek]]''. The series remained in Wilmington until 2003 when it was cancelled and replaced with ''[[One Tree Hill (TV series)|One Tree Hill]]''—a series on The WB/[[The CW Television Network|CW]] that calls North Carolina "home." ''One Tree Hill'' ended in 2012 after nine seasons.<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0368530/locations "ONE TREE HILL: Filming Locations"], ''Internet Movie Database'', Retrieved on 2007-11-19.</ref>
While Wilmington, NC continued to sustain itself with television, the international film climate began to shift out of North Carolina's favor. In an effort to keep production costs even cheaper, early 2000 saw [[Runaway production|production companies making films internationally]].<ref>Carvajal, Doreen [http://www.iht.com/articles/2005/05/18/news/cash.php "The Cannes Festival: A modern twist on 'location, location, location'"], ''International Herald Tribune'', May 18, 2005, Retrieved on 2007-11-19</ref> The North Carolina Film Commission was made most aware of this trend when it lost [[Charles Frazier]]'s North Carolina tale, ''[[Cold Mountain (film)|Cold Mountain]]'',<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0159365/locations "COLD MOUNTAIN: Filming Locations"], ''Internet Movie Database'', Retrieved on 2007-11-19.</ref> to the country of [[Romania]].<ref>Fellerath, David, [http://www.indyweek.com/gyrobase/Content?oid=oid%3A20684 "North Carolina gets its close-up"], ''Independent Weekly'', December 13, 2003, Retrieved 2007-11-19.</ref> Hoping to bring an international industry back to the United States, many law-makers across the US began creating incentives packages to encourage filming in individual states. North Carolina's legislature decided on pursuing a competitive incentive program.<ref>Sperling, Nicole, [http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/search/article_display.jsp?vnu_content_id=1498029 "North Carolina trying to lure more prod'ns"], ''The Hollywood Reporter'', May 22, 2002, Retrieved on 2007-11-19.</ref> On August 8, 2006, Governor [[Mike Easley|Mike F. Easley]] signed into law a legislation offering productions a full 15% tax credit on a minimum $250,000 spend in North Carolina (and not to exceed a $7.5M credit.) <ref>[http://www.ncfilm.com/incentives-benefits/nc-film-incentive.html "NC Film Incentive"], ''North Carolina Film Office'', Retrieved 2008-02-15.</ref> Since this program's inception, the NC Film Office has seen a substantial increase in production, as have other state's that have established similar programs.<ref>Donnahue, Ann, [http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/hr/content_display/news/e3i00627c6566fe8f5f2b526ecac90a53ee "MADE IN AMERICA: Incentive to stay"], ''The Hollywood Reporter'', November 1, 2006, Retrieved on 2007-11-20.</ref> Since 2006, the North Carolina Film Office has recruited the following films: [[George Clooney]]'s ''[[Leatherheads]]'' (2008),<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0379865/locations Leatherheads (2008) - Filming Locations - IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ''[[Nights in Rodanthe]]'' (2008) <ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0956038/locations Nights in Rodanthe (2008) - Filming Locations - IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> starring [[Richard Gere]] and [[Diane Lane]], ''[[The Marc Pease Experience]]'' (2008) <ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0913413/locations The Marc Pease Experience (2009) - Filming Locations - IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> with [[Ben Stiller]], and ''[[Bolden!]]'' (2008),<ref>[https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0858419/locations Bolden! (2014) - Filming Locations - IMDb<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> a film about the life of jazz legend [[Buddy Bolden]].
In September 2006, Commissioner Bill Arnold retired after 26 years of service to North Carolina's film industry.<ref>[http://www.ncfilm.com/news/31/115.html "State Film Office Hires New Director"], ''North Carolina Film Office'', March 3, 2007, Retrieved 2008-02-15.</ref> The North Carolina Film Office is now part of the NC Department of Commerce's Division of Tourism, Film and Sports Development. Aaron Syrett (former Director of the Utah Film Commission) was hired as Director of the North Carolina Film Office in spring 2007; his tenure ended at the end of July 2014.<ref>[http://www.afci.org/news/releases_10.htm "NC State Film Office Hires New Director"], ''Association of Film Commissioners International'', no date, Retrieved on 2007-11-20.</ref><ref name="wral.com">http://www.wral.com/state-film-commissioner-leaving-post/13794133/</ref> While building upon North Carolina's legacy, Syrett is taking a 21st-century approach to boost the global visibility of North Carolina's resources.<ref>[http://www.ncfilm.com/about-us.html ] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080118195655/http://www.ncfilm.com/about-us.html |date=January 18, 2008 }}</ref>
== Organization ==
=== Responsibilities === The North Carolina Film Office has 3 main responsibilities: market the State of North Carolina, serve the film industry, and serve the State of North Carolina. The office actively works to create a healthy climate in which to grow film industry economic development. A marketing agency as well, the film office educates the film industry on North Carolina's incentives program, promotes the state's infrastructure, and showcases North Carolina's diverse locations.
Projects (including film, television and commercial) are actively recruited and nurturted by the office. The office encourages industry-related companies to headquarter or have satellite companies in the state. The office ultimately serves the State of North Carolina by keeping and creating jobs in North Carolina for film crew and related businesses. As such, the film office must serve the film industry in an efficient and engaging capacity. The office hosts location scouts for producers and also provides on-the-ground assistance before and during filming. The North Carolina Film Office is the official liaison between the industry and state agencies for state property use, highway assistance, and other issues.
The office has always maintained sophisticated communications with the film industry. Not only has it maintained an informative website, but also it has supported the [[Full Frame Documentary Film Festival]] and for 9 years sponsored the [[American Film Market]]. Every spring the office participates in the [[Locations Trade Show]] hosted by the [[Association of Film Commissioners International]] in [[Santa Monica, California|Santa Monica, CA.]] Members of the office make regular trips to [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles, CA]] to meet with producers and also visit [[Park City, Utah|Park City, UT]] every January to network at the [[Sundance Film Festival]].
=== Regional Film Commissions === The North Carolina Film Office works in tandem with 6 affiliate offices that are both publicly and privately maintained. All are certified by the Association of Film Commissioners International.<ref>[http://www.ncfilm.com/filming-in-nc/affiliate-offices.html "Regional Commissions"], ''North Carolina Film Office'', Retrieved on 2007-11-20.</ref> * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071223141646/http://www.charlotteusa.com/Film/film_overview.asp Charlotte Regional Film Commission] <ref>[http://www.afci.org/wwwapps/profile.ami?workingSearchKeyword=north%20carolina&workingCommissionID=4467 "Charlotte Regional Film Commission"], ''Association of Film Commissioners International'', Retrieved on 2007-11-20.</ref> * [http://www.trianglencfilm.com/ Triangle Regional Film Commission] <ref>[http://www.afci.org/film-commissions/triangle-regional-film-commission], ''Association of Film Commissioners International'', Retrieved on 2015-02-18.</ref> * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071227230346/http://www.filmeast.net/portal/news.php Eastern North Carolina Regional Film Commission] <ref>[http://www.afci.org/wwwapps/profile.ami?workingSearchKeyword=north%20carolina&workingCommissionID=4756 "Eastern North Carolina Regional Film Commission"], ''Association of Film Commissioners International'', Retrieved on 2007-11-20.</ref> * [http://www.piedmontfilm.com/ Piedmont-Triad Film Commission] <ref>[http://www.afci.org/wwwapps/profile.ami?workingSearchKeyword=north%20carolina&workingCommissionID=4633 "Piedmont-Triad Film Commission"], ''Association of Film Commissioners International'', Retrieved on 2007-11-20.</ref> * [https://archive.is/20121208134939/http://www.advantagewest.com/content.cfm/content_id/152/section/film Western North Carolina Film Commission] <ref>[http://www.afci.org/wwwapps/profile.ami?workingSearchKeyword=north%20carolina&workingCommissionID=4710 "Western North Carolina Film Commission"], ''Association of Film Commissioners International'', Retrieved on 2007-11-20.</ref> * [http://www.wilmington-film.com/ Wilmington Regional Film Commission, Inc.] <ref>[http://www.afci.org/wwwapps/profile.ami?workingSearchKeyword=north%20carolina&workingCommissionID=4716 "Wilmington Regional Film Commission, Inc."], ''Association of Film Commissioners International'', Retrieved on 2007-11-20.</ref>
===Staff and Film Council=== The North Carolina Film Office has a 4-person staff. Until July 2014,<ref name="wral.com"/> the director of the North Carolina Film Office was Aaron Syrett (2007-2014). In addition to working with affiliate commissions, the North Carolina Film Office is also supported by a governor-appointed group who offer advice and guidance in the interest of North Carolina's film industry. Notable members include casting director, Craig Fincannon, founder of the [[Full Frame Documentary Film Festival]], Nancy Buirski, and former President of Universal Pictures, [[Thom Mount]]. Studio Executive [[Frank Capra, Jr.]] was also a member of the council until his death in 2007.<ref>[http://www.ncfilm.com/about-us/nc-film-council.html "North Carolina Film Council"], ''North Carolina Film Office'', Retrieved on 2008-02-15.</ref>
==Film Incentives Program== #As of January 2015, North Carolina has implemented a new Film and Entertainment Grant program. Funds from the $10 million grant will serve as a rebate of up to 25% on qualified expenses/purchases of productions. #The previous tax credit ended as of January 1, 2015. #Complete information on the new grant program is available at [http://www.nccommerce.com/film]
==Notable Films/Television made in North Carolina==

*''[[The Color Purple (1985 film)|The Color Purple]]'' *''[[The Crow (1994 film)|The Crow]]'' *''[[Dawson’s Creek]]'' *''[[Days of Thunder]]'' *''[[Dirty Dancing]]'' *''[[Divine Secrets of the Ya-Ya Sisterhood]]'' *''[[Dream a Little Dream (film)|Dream a Little Dream]]'' *''[[Eastbound and Down]]'' *''[[Empire Records]]'' *''[[Firestarter (film)|Firestarter]]'' *''[[Forrest Gump]]'' *''[[The Fugitive (1993 film)|The Fugitive]]'' *''[[Ghosts In The Ballpark--History of the Durham Bulls]]'' *''[[The Green Mile (film)|The Green Mile]]'' *''[[Hannibal (film)|Hannibal]]'' *''[[Homeland (TV series)|Homeland]]'' *''[[The Hunt for Red October (film)|The Hunt for Red October]]'' *''[[The Hunger Games (film)|The Hunger Games]]'' *''[[I Know What You Did Last Summer]]'' *''[[Iron Man 3]]'' *''[[Junebug (film)|Junebug]]'' *''[[Kiss the Girls (film)|Kiss the Girls]]'' *''[[Last of the Mohicans (1992 film)|Last of the Mohicans]]'' *''[[Leatherheads]]'' *''[[Legacy of the Golden Leaf-- A page.title: Opie and Anthony's Traveling Virus Comedy Tour (2008)

revision.comment: Past tense
revision.text:
{{Infobox concert tour | | concert_tour_name = [[Opie and Anthony's Traveling Virus Comedy Tour]] | artist = [[Opie and Anthony]] | start_date = September 2, 2008 | end_date = September 2, 2008 | number_of_legs = 1 | number_of_shows = 1 | type = [[Stand-up comedy]] | location = New Jersey | last_tour = '''Last'''
[[Opie and Anthony's Traveling Virus Comedy Tour (2007)|2007]] | this_tour = '''Current'''
2008 | next_tour = '''Next'''
None }} '''Opie and Anthony's Traveling Virus''' was the final of three [[Opie and Anthony's Traveling Virus Comedy Tour|comedy event series]], [[concert tour]] starring [[comedian]]s featured on [[Opie and Anthony]], a talk radio show which aired on [[XM Satellite Radio]]. It was the third annual Traveling Virus tour, the first [[Opie and Anthony's Traveling Virus Comedy Tour (2006)|one]] occurring in 2006 in four different US cities, and the [[Opie and Anthony's Traveling Virus Comedy Tour (2007)|second]] in 2007.[http://www.laughspin.com/2007/06/11/opie-anthony-something-wickedly-funny-this-way-comes/ Opie & Anthony: Something Wickedly Funny This Way Comes] ==History== The tour was a goal of Opie and Anthony's since coming together as a radio talk duo in [[Long Island]] in the early 1990s.{{cn|date=February 2015}} The tour was intended to reward the comedians that had been guesting on the show over the years, and to serve as a thank you to fans nationwide.{{cn|date=February 2015}} They were finally able to present the tour in 2006 because of their terrestrial radio deal with CBS. The 2006 tour was notable for the Philadelphia incident where comedian [[Bill Burr]] went on a 12-minute tirade attacking the audience after the previous act, [[Dom Irrera]], was heckled heavily by the crowd.[http://www.huffingtonpost.com/jonathan-valania/the-mouth-that-roared-qa-_b_4242841.html The Mouth That Roared: Q&A With Comedian Bill Burr, The Man Who Told Philadelphia To Go F*ck Itself, Hard, And Lived To Tell] At many of the shows that followed the fans would boo the comedians in order to try and relive the same excitement as Philadelphia. The 2008 full tour was eventually canceled in favor of one final show held on August 2 2008.[http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv-movies/970-lineup-talk-article-1.315712 970 AM's lineup could be all the talk] According to Opie and Anthony the tour was cancelled due to the crowd consistently booing new comedians off the stage.[http://www.shayne-michael.com/links.php?searchFor=Jim%20Norton&findBio=full Jim Norton Biography] ==Tour schedule== The following was the 2008 show date: {| border="2px" cellpadding="4px" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 1em 1em 1em 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse;" |- bgcolor="#CCCCCC" ! August 2, [[Holmdel, New Jersey]] - ''[[PNC Bank Arts Center]]'':[http://www.nj.com/news/index.ssf/2008/04/poprockby_jay_lustiglongtime_p.html Summer concert schedule for PNC Bank Arts Center announced] |- | [[Jim Norton (comedian)|Jim Norton]] |- | [[Patrice Oneal]] |- | [[Mike Birbiglia]] |- | [[Greg Giraldo]] |- | [[Robert Kelly (comedian)|Bob Kelly]] |- | [[Rich Vos]] |- | [[Otto & George]] |- | [[Mike Destefano]] |- | [[Jim Breuer]] (unannounced) |} ==References== {{reflist}} {{Opie and Anthony}} [[Category:Comedy tours]]

'''Committee of Radio and Television "Polish Radio and Television"''' ({{lang-pl|Komitet do Spraw Radia i Telewizji "Polskie Radio i Telewizja"}}) (also called as a Radiocomittee - Radiokomitet) was an institution, which managed all stations of Polish Television and Polish Radio in [[People's Republic of Poland]] (PRL) and in [[Republic of Poland]]. It was replaced by two separate entities in 1993 - [[Polskie Radio|Polish Radio]] and [[Telewizja Polska|Polish Television]].

revision.comment: sp.: [[International Labour Organization]], per [[MOS:CONSISTENCY]], proper names use the subject's own spelling (via [[WP:JWB]])
revision.text:
'''Prostitution in Finland''' (the exchange of sexual services for money) is legal but soliciting in a public place, organized prostitution (operating a [[brothel]] or a prostitution ring and other forms of [[Procuring (prostitution)|pimping]]) is illegal.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/2007/100558.htm |title=Country Report on Human Rights Practices in Finland |publisher=US State Department |date=March 11, 2008 |accessdate=June 4, 2014}}</ref> According to a 2010 [[TAMPEP]] study, 69% of prostitutes working in Finland are migrants.<ref name="euobserver.com">{{cite web|last=Rettman |first=Andrew |url=http://euobserver.com/9/29340 |title=Romanian sex workers most prevalent in EU/ Social Affairs / Romanian sex workers most prevalent in EU |publisher=EU Observer |date=January 26, 2010 |accessdate=June 4, 2014}}</ref> As of 2009, there was little 'visible' prostitution in Finland as it was mostly limited to private residences and nightclubs in larger metropolitan areas.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.state.gov/g/drl/rls/hrrpt/2009/eur/136030.htm |title=2009 Human Rights Report: Finland |publisher=US State Department |date=2010-03-11 |accessdate=2012-08-15}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Sex industry in Finland becoming more international |url=http://www.helsinkitimes.fi/finland/finland-news/domestic/2496-sex-industry-in-finland-becoming-more-international-2.html |website=www.helsinkitimes.fi |accessdate=25 July 2018 |language=en-gb |date=6 June 2012}}</ref>
== History ==
The socio-legal history of prostitution in Finland is similar to that of other European and Western countries, with various periods of tolerance, regulation and abolition.
===18th century - early 20th century===
The passing of the [[Civil Code of 1734]] was the first nation-wide law for all of Sweden, as well as Finland, that prohibited prostitution.<ref name="auto">Venla Roth [https://books.google.com.mx/books?id=ZVkyAQAAQBAJ&pg=PP3&source=gbs_selected_pages&cad=2#v=onepage&q&f=false''Defining Human Trafficking and Identifying Its Victims: A Study on the Impact and Future Challenges of International, European and Finnish Legal Responses to Prostitution-Related Trafficking in Human Beings''] (Martinus Nijhoff Publishers, Boston, 2011).</ref> The historical position of [[sexual morality]] was based on the [[Christian]] standard of condemning both premarital and extramarital sexual relations. These religious values were reflected in the common law across Europe and most Western societies throughout this period.<ref name="auto"/>
The next major development came in the form of the 1889 Penal Code of Finland,<ref>[https://prostitution.procon.org/sourcefiles/FinlandPenalCode.pdf "The Penal Code of Finland 1899".] Retrieved 5 September 2017.</ref> which prohibited both [[Procuring (prostitution)|pandering]] and prostitution. The code extended the prohibition to cover ‘any professional fornication’, meaning the law would not tolerate prostitution no matter where it was taking place. International activism concerning prostitution at the end of the 19th century transformed the societal view of prostitution as an aspect of urban life to one which perceived the labour as a social problem.<ref name="auto1">Greggor Mattson [https://books.google.co.nz/books?id=3VR7CwAAQBAJ&source=gbs_navlinks_s ''The Cultural Politics of European Prostitution Reform: Governing Loose Women''] (Palsgrave Macmillan, Hampshire, 2016).</ref> This evolution demanded the removal of prostitutes from the public eye through criminalisation of the female prostitutes as delinquents.<ref name="auto1"/>
From 1937 to 1986 the Vagrancy Act was also in effect in Finland. In accordance with the legislation prostitutes could be taken under control and given orders by the police and social and health care authorities.<ref name="auto2">Marjut Jyrkinen [https://helda.helsinki.fi/dhanken/bitstream/handle/10227/118/146-951-555-882-4.pdf?sequence=2''The Organisation of Policy Meets the Commercialisation of Sex: Global Linkages, Policies, Technologies''] (Helsingfors, Helsinki, 2005).</ref> This could include interrogations, sending to institutions, arrests, obligations to undergo health examinations and various other regulatory requests.<ref name="auto"/><ref>[http://www.housingrightswatch.org/sites/default/files/2012-12-11_RPT_FINLAND_anti_soc_laws_en.pdf Housing Rights Watch "Finland"] (2012)</ref>
Activism after [[World War II]] and the gradual 20th century abandoning of the standard of absolute sexual morality again shifted social perceptions of prostitution.<ref name="auto"/> The economic depression, alongside other structural and political reasons, contributed to an increase in the sex trade after the Second World War.<ref name="auto2"/> The universal human rights movement of the time pushed for the decriminalisation of prostitution so as not to punish women who were victims of poverty or exploitation.<ref name="auto1"/>
===Late 20th century – present===
The geopolitical position of Finland, and its position in the [[European Union]] as of 1995, had a significant influence on the sex trade in the 1990s.<ref name="auto2"/> Access to sex services became increasingly easier across most cities and rural areas in Finland during this time. The established political connection with Western Europe allowed people to move more freely across borders and hence engage in the sex services market in Finland.<ref>Charlotta Holmstrom and May-Len Skilbrei [http://www.nikk.no/wp-content/uploads/NIKKpub2008_prostitution_conferanceEng1.pdf "Prostitution in the Nordic Countries"] (Nordic Gender Institute, Conference report, Stockholm, 16–17 October 2008).</ref> Authorities estimated that in the 1990s the amount of prostitutes working in Finland was approximately 2000, with 200 of these being of foreign origin.<ref name="auto2"/> The effects of [[economic depression]], mass unemployment and the resulting economic position of women also contributed to the intensification in the volume and forms of national prostitution.<ref>Antti Häkkinen [https://books.google.co.nz/books/about/Rahasta_vaan_ei_rakkaudesta.html?id=SSoJPQAACAAJ&redir_esc=y ''Rahasta - vaan ei rakkaudesta: prostituutio Helsingissä 1867-1939''] (Otava, Helsinki, 1995).</ref> The increased trend of [[transnational organised crime]] in pandering and [[human trafficking]] operations shifted public concern from the protection of public morality to protection of public order and security.<ref name="auto"/>
The [[Protocol to Prevent, Suppress and Punish Trafficking in Persons, especially Women and Children|UN Trafficking Protocol]], adopted in Finland in 2000, and the European Union Council Framework Decision on combating trafficking in human beings,<ref>T Pedersen [https://ec.europa.eu/anti-trafficking/sites/antitrafficking/files/framework_decision_2002_629_on_combating_trafficking_en_1.pdf “Council Framework Decision of 19 July 2002 on Combating Trafficking in Human Beings"] (2002) 629 JHA 203.</ref> adopted in 2002, both obligated cooperating states to criminalise trafficking and increase border control to prevent transnational organised crime.<ref name="auto"/> These international obligations acted as the starting point for the restructuring of prostitution legislation in Finland. In 2003 both the purchasing and selling of sexual services were prohibited under Finnish law where either occurred in a public place.
== Types of Prostitution ==
=== Street Prostitution === [[Street prostitution]] consisted of both foreign and native prostitutes; however, a majority of the bunch are foreign prostitutes. This was made up of the female prostitutes and males referred to as "[[Kerb crawler|kerb-crawlers]]" that sought out the services of the female prostitutes. Street prostitution made its way to the center of the capital city of Helsinki where it became very popular with about 50 street prostitutes.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Tani|first=Sirpa|date=June 2002|title=Whose Place is This Space? Life in the Street Prostitution Area of Helsinki, Finland|journal=International Journal of Urban and Regional Research|language=en|volume=26|issue=2|pages=343–359|doi=10.1111/1468-2427.00383|issn=0309-1317}}</ref> Local residents of Helsinki were upset with the allowance of street prostitution in their neighborhoods, so in 1994 a female activist group formed in order to abolish street prostitution as a whole. They started the movement called "Prostitution Off the Streets" where they patrolled the streets at night for any potential street prostitution as well as initiated a petition against street prostitution.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=MMjfCgAAQBAJ&pg=PA290&lpg=PA290&dq=Prostitution+Off+The+Streets+movement+finland#v=onepage&q=Prostitution%20Off%20The%20Streets%20movement%20finland&f=false|title=The Urban Sociology Reader|last=Lin|first=Jan|last2=Mele|first2=Christopher|date=2012-11-12|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9781136244155|language=en}}</ref> This type of prostitution was legal until 1999 when laws prohibited prostitution in public spaces. This new law pushed the business of street prostitution north to the city of Vantaa until a year later when Vantaa also began prohibiting prostitution in public spaces.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Niemi|first=Johanna and Jussi Aaltonen|date=April 2013|title=Abuse of a victim of prostitution: Evaluation of the effectiveness of the sex purchase ban|url=https://ec.europa.eu/anti-trafficking/sites/antitrafficking/files/abuse_of_a_victim_of_prostitution_evaluation_of_the_effectiveness_of_the_sex_purchase_ban_en_0.pdf|journal=Kuvailulehti|volume=|pages=121|via=}}</ref>
=== Online Prostitution === The Internet has become a popular place for advertising business; prostitution is no exception. Pictures of prostitutes and their services began being advertised online with about 80%-90% of the industry utilizing the internet in some capacity to advertise.<ref name=":0" /> In the early 2000’s, Finland removed servers that advertised prostitution due to ‘[[Procuring (prostitution)|procuring]]’ that the Criminal Code has outlined since 2004. However, these operations are still being run remotely in countries such as Spain. This makes it difficult for police to take action against ‘procuring’ online because, as behind the scenes operations are being taken care of remotely, they cannot trace any of the activity; they can only uncover the prostitute.<ref name=":0" />
=== Erotic Restaurants === Restaurants became a location for a lot of foreign prostitutes in Finland to sell their services, particularly in the city center of Helsinki. Restaurants were willing to partake in this form of prostitution because they were able to make a profit off of the prostitutes by charging them a fee when entering the restaurant for business as well as when they leave with a client.<ref name=":0" /> In addition to the fees, the women in erotic restaurants also lured more traffic into the restaurants which allowed the restaurants to profit even further. In the grand scheme of things, Finland as a whole also technically benefits from erotic restaurants as they are legal establishments that pay taxes so when these women create more clients for the restaurants, more money goes to taxes.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/82367747|title=Globalization, prostitution and sex-trafficking : corporeal politics|last=Elina.|first=Penttinen,|date=2008|publisher=Routledge|isbn=9780415420990|location=London|oclc=82367747}}</ref>
=== Newspaper Ads === In Finland, newspaper publications promoted prostitution. This was a pretty common form of advertising before the introduction of online prostitution in the early 2000s. However, the newspapers were not blatant in their advertising. They used phrases such as 'company for daytime coffee' to suggest prostitution.<ref name=":0" /> Occasionally, the ads would reference a “massage”, which was also a phrase that soon became synonymous with prostitution. In addition to these phrases, the newspaper ad included a phone number for the potential clients to call to obtain the desired services. Most of the newspaper ad clients, specifically, were men from Finland rather than foreign clients.<ref name=":2" /> Newspaper ads for prostitution are no longer common due to the changing technological times.
== Legal framework ==
Buying or attempting to buy sex from a minor is illegal.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/teen_prostitution_a_silent_problem_in_finland/6671108|title=Teen prostitution a silent problem in Finland|website=Yle Uutiset|accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref> The Public Law and Order Act prohibits offering or buying sex in a public place. Although prostitution has become legal, [[Procuring (prostitution)|procuring]] still remains illegal. Procuring includes anything that would be considered the organization or facilitation of services for prostitutes.<ref name=":1" /> The criminalisation of the purchase of sex from adults has been a continuing topic of discussion in the Nordic countries. In June 2006, [[Eduskunta|parliament]] voted by 158 to 15 with four abstentions to approve a bill which outlaws the buying of sexual services from sex workers if it is linked to [[human trafficking]].<ref name=swhealth>{{cite web|url=http://www.finnbay.com/media/news/sex-workers-finland-healthy-government-reports/?PageSpeed=noscriptSex|title=Sex Workers in Finland Are Healthy, Government Reports|website=Finnbay.com|accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/5103132.stm|title=BBC NEWS - Europe - Finns pass anti-prostitution law|publisher=|accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref> The issue was raised again in 2013 by the Justice Minister.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://yle.fi/uutiset/justice_minister_to_seek_full_ban_on_purchasing_sex/6814089|title=Justice Minister to seek full ban on purchasing sex|website=Yle Uutiset|accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref> The current legal position in Finland therefore allows for the private sale of sexual services, for example in brothels, but any form of human trafficking is both against the law and in breach of international human rights obligations.
Venla Roth comments that the current Finnish penal position can be seen as a compromise between the two conflicting positions on the legality of prostitution.<ref name="auto"/>
==Foreign prostitutes==
A significant number of the prostitutes working in Finland are foreign. The proportion of the prostitutes that are migrants has increased over time, largely due to increased accessibility, political positions and economic factors.<ref name="auto3">Jaana Kauppinen and Essi Thesslund [http://tbinternet.ohchr.org/Treaties/CEDAW/Shared%20Documents/FIN/INT_CEDAW_NGO_FIN_16298_E.pdf ''Trafficking and Exploitation of Prostitution''] (Pro-tukipiste, Submission to the Committee on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women, 31 January 2014).</ref> This increased accessibility may be attributed to the geographic location of Finland because of its proximity to other European countries as well as the fact that Finland is considered to be a transit country.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.helsinki.fi/akka-info/FWS.html|title=Women's Studies in Finland|last=all/SUNS|website=www.helsinki.fi|access-date=2018-07-17}}</ref>
In 1999 a special section was enacted under the Aliens Act<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.finlex.fi/en/laki/kaannokset/2004/en20040301.pdf|title=Aliens Act 2004 (Finland)|publisher=}}</ref> in Finland. It specifies that where there are reasonable grounds to suspect an alien may sell sexual services he or she may be refused entrance into the country. The provision was justified as an objective to protect Finnish citizens from the social disturbances caused by prostitutes coming in from the East.<ref name="auto"/>
===Statistics===
Following the enactment of the special provision, between 1999 and 2007, Border Guard authorities refused the entry of more than 1730 persons on the grounds of suspicion that they sold sexual services or had earned their income though dishonest means.<ref name="auto"/> By 2006 this number had escalated to 3300 refusals.<ref name="auto"/> These figures continue to increase, with Finnish police reporting that during the years of 2011 and 2012 there were more persons than ever deported because of suspicions of the sale of sexual services.<ref name="auto3"/>
Despite legislative prevention measures, there continues to be a significant number of foreign prostitutes working in Finland. The National Bureau of Investigation estimated in 2002 that the annual number of foreign prostitutes was between 10,000 and 15,000, with most of them originating from Russia and Estonia but also from other European countries.<ref name="auto"/> [[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women|The Committee on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women]] (CEDAW) noted that the majority of prostitutes working in Finland are estimated to be either foreigners living permanently in Finland or travelling from country to country under tourist visas.<ref name="auto4">Committee on the Elimination of Discrimination against Women [https://documents-dds-ny.un.org/doc/UNDOC/GEN/G13/411/12/PDF/G1341112.pdf?OpenElement ''Consideration of reports submitted by States parties under article 18 of the Convention''] (United Nations, Seventh periodic reports of states parties, 11 May 2012).</ref> The [[National Bureau of Investigation (Finland)|Finnish Bureau of Investigation]] suspects that almost all of these foreign prostitutes work under the control of organised procurers.<ref name="auto"/>
===Implications and objections===
The Aliens Act and the enforcement of the refusal to enter by authorities has been subject to polarised opinions and various human rights concerns.
In 2003 the National Bureau of Investigation stated trafficking of human beings for the purposes of sexual exploitation did not occur in Finland, and said that all foreign prostitutes were “fully aware of the nature and conditions of the work”.<ref name="auto"/> This statement, and the 1999 amendment of the Aliens Act, have however been severely critiqued on the basis that they ignore the disadvantaged status of foreign prostitutes.<ref name="auto3"/> Marte Mesna argues that deporting foreigners where they are suspected of coming into the country to sell sex portrays that when there are people other than citizens involved, “it is the prostitutes who suddenly become the problem again”.<ref name="auto5">Marte Mesna [http://www.nikk.no/en/news/mixed-signals-in-nordic-prostitution-policy/ "Mixed signals in Nordic prostitution policy"] (14 November 2013) Nordic Information on Gender.</ref> Venla Roth also argues along these lines, claiming that placing foreign prostitutes outside of the public system means they are not protected and are more vulnerable to exploitation.<ref name="auto"/> Knowledge that a person has sold sexual services in the past constitutes reasonable grounds to believe he or she intends to do it again, hence qualifying as a ground for denial of entrance into Finland.<ref name="auto"/>
== National advocacy ==
Pro-tukipiste r.y. (Pro Centre Finland),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pro-tukipiste.fi/|title=Prostituution, seksityön ja ihmiskaupan asiantuntija Pro-tukipiste|date=31 January 2014|publisher=|accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref> a registered non-profit organisation, supports and promotes the civil and human rights of sex workers in Finland, offering professional social support, health care services and legal advice, operating in Helsinki and Tampere. Services are provided without charge, anonymously, and the centre is politically and religiously independent. It also offers consultation on issues concerning sex work and human trafficking. They are a partner in the Indoors Project, a European Union initiative for analysis and policy recommendations on sex work inside the EU.
Pro-tukipiste estimates that the number of individual persons in contact with the organisation and their services each year is between 1500 and 2000.<ref name="auto3"/> The majority of these people are women with migrant backgrounds.
On a smaller scale, a union group by the name of [[Salli|SALLI]], United Sex Professionals formed in 2002, also aimed to protect the human rights of sex workers in Finland.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/314828868|title=Sex worker union organising : an international study|last=Gregor.|first=Gall,|date=2006|publisher=Palgrave Macmillan|others=Palgrave Connect (Online service)|isbn=9780230502482|location=Basingstoke [England]|oclc=314828868}}</ref> The group of 9 sex workers that founded this organization focused on "sex workers' human rights in terms of their well being, safety at work, professional skills, and control of workplace working conditions".<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/936429868|title=Sex worker unionization : global developments, challenges and possibilities|last=Gregor,|first=Gall,|isbn=9781137320131|location=New York|oclc=936429868|date=2016-02-29}}</ref>
==Political and social debates==
Legislation concerning the purchase of sexual services remains subject to ongoing debate in Finland and the wider Nordic region.<ref>Ida Måwe [http://www.nikk.no/en/news/debate-on-sex-purchase-legislation-keeps-simmering/ "Debate on sex purchase legislation keeps simmering"] (17 February 2015) Nordic Information on Gender.</ref> The two fundamental polarised views are those promoting legalisation of the profession and those promoting total abolition.
===Legalisers===
Legaliser is the term given to those who advocate for the rights of prostitutes, including the right to work. It is argued that the [[United Nations]] resolutions guaranteeing the right to work, such as the 1988 [[International Labour Organization]] recognition of sex work, align with promoting the rights of sex workers.<ref name="auto1"/>
The [[U.S. Department of State]]'s [[Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor]], in its annual [[Country Report on Human Rights Practices]] for Finland, discuss discrimination in respect to employment and occupation in their 2016 report on Finland.<ref>Rex W. Tillerson [https://www.state.gov/j/drl/rls/hrrpt/humanrightsreport/index.htm#wrapper ''Country Reports on Human Rights Practices for 2016: Finland''] (Bureau of Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, 2016).</ref> While the Bureau does not explicitly state the law on prostitution to be in breach of the right to work, those who adopt the legaliser approach stress this relationship.
===Abolitionists===
Abolitionists are the people whom advocate for the opposing view in relation to prostitution. This argument is largely based on United Nations statements against prostitution from the early days of the [[League of Nations]] and the Palermo Protocol (2002) on preventing trafficking in persons, especially women and children.<ref name="auto1"/> This position reflects the increased public concern about human trafficking and its connection to prostitution.
The [[Ministry of Social Affairs and Health]] in Finland started a five-year national programme for the Prevention of Prostitution and Violence against Women from 1998 to 2002, demonstrating its preference of total prohibition.<ref name="auto6">Women's Studies in Finland [http://www.helsinki.fi/akka-info/FWS.html#PREVENTION%20OF%20PROSTITUTION%201998%20- "Prevention of Prostitution 1998-2002"] (April 1999).</ref> The Minister of Social Affairs and Health, who chaired this programme, claims the negative health implications of prostitution raise concerns related to human rights and ethics.<ref name="auto6"/> Finland’s Minister of Justice, [[Anna-Maja Henriksson]], argued for total prohibition of all forms of sex purchase in 2012.<ref name="auto5"/>
===Nordic model===
The [[Prostitution in Sweden|Nordic Model]] refers to the legal position of Sweden where it is illegal to buy sexual services but the sale of one’s own body for the sexual services is not illegal. This position attempts to reduce the demand for prostitution by punishing the clients instead of the prostitutes.<ref name="auto7">Bosse Parbring [http://www.nikk.no/en/news/european-parliament-wants-to-punish-the-clients-of-prostitution/ "European Parliament wants to punish the clients of prostitution"] (27 February 2014) Nordic Information on Gender.</ref> The European Parliament advanced in a non-binding resolution passed on 26 February 2014 that all EU countries should adopt this approach.<ref>European Parliament [http://www.europarl.europa.eu/news/en/press-room/20140221IPR36644/punish-the-client-not-the-prostitute "Punish the client, not the prostitute"] (press release, 26 February 2014).</ref> It was emphasised that prostitution as a profession violates human dignity and human rights whether the work is forced or voluntary. The European Parliament therefore focuses on finding exit strategies and alternative sources of income for women working as prostitutes. This resolution, calling on the example of the Nordic model, was adopted by 343 votes to 139, with 105 abstentions.<ref name="auto7"/>
===International input===
In September 2009 the Ministry of Justice submitted a report to Parliament.<ref name="auto4"/> The report discussed the link between the demand for sexual services and human trafficking for the purposes of sexual exploitation. CEDAW however stress that the prevalence of trafficking is also influenced by multiple other factors, including those relating to economic and political instability. They therefore advance that it is important to view prostitution and the demand for sexual services and trafficking from a broad, holistic point of view.<ref name="auto4"/>
Pro-tukipiste also provides their perspective in relation to the information in the Ministry of Justice report. They claim the data is bias, narrow and questionable with no voice given to those who sell the sexual services.<ref name="auto3"/> It is also suggested by the organisation in their own studies that the current law in Finland has caused the position of prostitutes to deteriorate, the risk of violence to increase and has introduced further negative impacts for foreign workers.<ref name="auto3"/>
The United States attributed Finland a Tier 2 rating through their State Department Trafficking in Person (TIP) Report League in 2003.<ref>U.S. Department of State [https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/21555.pdf ''Trafficking in Persons Report''] (Office of the Under Secretary for Global Affairs, June 2003).</ref> Alongside Uganda and Albania, Finland was given this rating on the basis of rumours of ‘enclosed prostitution camps’. The Finnish Minister of Justice and several EU allies rebutted the US claims.<ref name="auto1"/>
=== Social Perspectives === Over time, prostitution has become more accepted by people, prodominately men, in Finland. The 2012 Gender Equality Barometer study showed that from 2004 to 2008, only 60% of men found it socially acceptable to pay prostitutes for sex. However, that number increased to 66% of males in 2012.<ref name=":0" /> This study also showed that men find it more socially acceptable to pay for sex than women do, as they are the main clientele for prostitution services. However, the amount of men that actually reported purchasing sex in the Finsex survey conducted in 2007, was significantly lower around about 3% of men.<ref name=":0" /> Men buying services from prostitutes view it as a normal behavior that speaks to their sexuality. Weather these men are using prostitution as a way to avoid relationships or responsibilities, they enjoy the feeling of power they achieve through these acts.<ref name=":0" />
In contrast, prostitution was often controversial for those opposed to it as it was synonymous with drugs, crime, and immoral behavior.<ref name=":1" /> Street prostitution, specifically, was seen by residents as a downturn in their neighborhoods. Residents of neighborhoods in which street prostitution became increasingly popular viewed it as an issue of morality. They believed it was their moral duty to "clean" the streets of these prostitutes, because of the negative connotations it brought to their neighborhoods, which they believed would create a better environment for everyone.<ref name=":3" />
== Research ==
The health of sex workers in Finland has been an ongoing project of the Finnish Government<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thl.fi/fi/web/thlfi-en/research-and-expertwork/projects-and-programmes/projects/30576|title=Prostitution and health in Finland|website=National Institute for Health and Welfare|accessdate=22 December 2014}}</ref> and data suggests a good level of health, and in particular an absence of [[sexually transmitted diseases]].<ref name=swhealth/>
The National Council of Women in Finland notes that obtaining evidence and research on the purchase of sexual services overall has proven difficult in practice, particularly from procured prostitutes.<ref name="auto"/> The Association suggests that authorities must either allocate sufficient resources to the enforcement of the current penal provision or reconsider the most appropriate legal position.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.naisjarjestot.fi|title=Etusivu - Naisjärjestöjen Keskusliitto|website=www.naisjarjestot.fi}}</ref><ref name="auto"/>
==Sex trafficking== {{see also|Human trafficking in Finland}} Finland is a transit, destination, and limited source country for women and girls subjected to [[sex trafficking]]. Traffickers operate from abroad using threats of violence, debt leverage, and other forms of coercion. Victims originate primarily in [[Eastern Europe]], [[West Africa]], and [[Asia]]. Authorities report a surge in potential trafficking victims among rejected asylum-seekers returning to Finland under the [[Dublin Regulation|Dublin Agreement]], including a rise in the number of individuals exploited prior to their arrival in Finland, such as [[Nigeria]]n women who account for the majority of sex trafficking victims.<ref name="state18">{{cite web |title=Finland 2018 Trafficking in Persons Report |url=https://www.state.gov/j/tip/rls/tiprpt/countries/2018/282655.htm |website=U.S. Department of State |accessdate=28 July 2018}}{{PD-notice}}</ref>
The [[United States Department of State]] [[Office to Monitor and Combat Trafficking in Persons]] ranks Finland as a '[[Trafficking in Persons Report#Ranking System|Tier 1]]' country.<ref name="state18" />
== References == {{Reflist}}

State feminism, women's movements and prostitution policies in Finland, in Joyce Outshoorn (ed.) The Politics of Prostitution: Women's Movements, Democratic States and the Globalisation of Sex Commerce. Cambridge University Press 2004] * [http://www.jhubc.it/ecpr-bologna/docs/561.pdf Anne Maria Holli. Debating prostitution/trafficking in Sweden and Finland. 2004] * [http://www.nikk.no/wp-content/uploads/NIKKpub2008_prostitution_conferanceEng1.pdf Charlotta Holmström & May-Len Skilbrei. Prostitution in the Nordic Countries. 2008] * [https://books.google.com/books?id=CkCiAgAAQBAJ Charlotta Holmström, May-Len Skilbrei. Prostitution Policy in the Nordic Region: Ambiguous Sympathies. Ashgate 2013] * [http://heuni.fi/material/attachments/heuni/reports/6KjPMW3Ad/Report_38.pdf Matti Lehti and Kauko Aroma. Trafficking in Human Beings, Illegal Immigration and Finland. 2002] * [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=2274607 Gregg Bucken-Knapp, Johan Karlsson Schaffer, Pia Levin. Comrades, Push The Red Button! Prohibiting the Purchase of Sexual Services in Sweden but Not in Finland 2012] ([http://www.mothugg.se/2014/04/02/nytt-kapitel-om-prostitutionspolitik-i-sverige-och-finland/ excerpt]) * [http://papers.ssrn.com/sol3/papers.cfm?abstract_id=1452294 Gregg Bucken-Knapp, Johan Karlsson, Karin Persson Strömbäck. Prostitution Policy Reform and the Causal Role of Ideas: A Comparative Study of Policy-Making in the Nordic Countries. 2009] * [https://www.researchgate.net/publication/237575110_Eastern_Prostitution_from_Russia_to_Sweden_and_Finland Tage Alalehto. Eastern Prostitution from Russia to Sweden and Finland. Journal of Scandinavian Studies in Criminology and Crime Prevention 01/2002; 3(1):96-111. DOI:10.1080/140438502762467236]

What's up Finland 4 June 2012] * [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m5i0EKpyP6c Jaana Kauppinen (Pro-tukipiste) talks about sex work in Finland. Video Dec 17 2013] * [http://theconversation.com/the-nordic-model-of-prostitution-law-is-a-myth-21351 May-Len Skilbrei, Charlotta Holmström. The ‘Nordic model’ of prostitution law is a myth. The Conversation 16 December 2013] * [http://web.b.ebscohost.com.ezproxy.canterbury.ac.nz/ehost/pdfviewer/pdfviewer?vid=1&sid=a3c113f1-557a-4aa9-9f4a-aa41f3fedb74%40sessionmgr101 Sirpa Tani ''Whose Place is This Space? Life in the Street Prostitution Area of Helsinki, Finland'' (International Journal of Urban & Regional Research, June 2002).] * [http://gr2tq4rz9x.search.serialssolutions.com/?ctx_ver=Z39.88-2004&ctx_enc=info%3Aofi%2Fenc%3AUTF-8&rfr_id=info%3Asid%2Fsummon.serialssolutions.com&rft_val_fmt=info%3Aofi%2Ffmt%3Akev%3Amtx%3Ajournal&rft.genre=article&rft.atitle=Eastern+prostitution+from+Russia+to+Sweden+and+Finland&rft.jtitle=Journal+of+Scandinavian+Studies+in+Criminology+%26+Crime+Prevention&rft.au=Tage+Alalehto&rft.date=2002-01-01&rft.pub=Taylor+%26+Francis+Group&rft.issn=1404-3858&rft.volume=3&rft.issue=1&rft.spage=96&rft.externalDocID=621634041&paramdict=en-NZ Tage Alalehto ''Eastern Prostitution from Russia to Sweden and Finland'' (Journal of Scandinavian Studies in Criminology and Crime Prevention, November 2010).] * [http://journals.sagepub.com.ezproxy.canterbury.ac.nz/doi/pdf/10.1177/1477370809347945 Minna Viuhko ''Human Trafficking for Sexual Exploitation and Organized Procuring in Finland'' (European Journal of Criminology, 2010).] * [http://ebookcentral.proquest.com.ezproxy.canterbury.ac.nz/lib/canterbury/reader.action?docID=255222 Joyce Outshoorn ''The Politics of Prostitution : Women's Movements, Democratic States and the Globalisation of Sex Commerce'' (Cambridge University Press, Cambridge, 2004).] * [http://journals.sagepub.com.ezproxy.canterbury.ac.nz/doi/full/10.1177/1403494813492031 Elena Regushevskaya, Elina Haavio-Mannila, Elina Hemminki ''Sociodemographic characteristics and attitudes of men buying sex in Finland'' (Scandinavian Journal of Public Health, June 2013).]
